1.content:
Welcome to Gerbert Gerbil & the Cosmic Crew, a space themed family dining, arcade complex and party center! Where kids and parents alike come for entertainment and food as far as the eye can see, populated with state of the art animatronic characters and automated systems. Full tummies are happy tummies and the staff at Gerbert Gerbil’s strives to make every meal, birthday and gathering an event.

Join heroic astronaut Gerbert Gerbil in his far out adventures alongside the Cosmic Crew: Hippo Don the musician/gangster hippo, Moolia the hybrid cow and dessert maker, and Fuchsia the color changing dancing flamingo. The Cosmic Crew’s adventure shows include other characters, aliens and robots, most persistently Gerbert’s rival astronaut Hamster Louie.

With lavish game ‘n’ activity areas, spectacular special effects and good food surely there could be no funner place on earth, right?

Well, even a family dining & leisure business can host its own share of less-than-innocent horrors. Peer past the childlike wonder of the place and Gerbert Gerbil’s is in pretty dire straits. Cosmic Crew Entertainment has been hyper focused on the cartoons and merchandizing of Gerbert and the gang that they throw money around get rid of problems. Short sighted, bribed ‘solutions’ that only end up making things worse. With health and safety inspections paid off rather than earned the restaurant faces many issues. The complex automated systems are glitchy, the food quality is much less than it appears, the overstressed employees try to get away with questionable activities during work hours and sometimes there’s just something off, you know, with the animatronics. Cosmic Crew Entertainment also denies there being any reports of missing children, possible murders, employee or customer injury or the chance of the whole establishment being haunted.

This story looks to delve into the lives of those that work or frequent Gerbert Gerbil’s, both the horrific consequences of their association with the franchise and the fattening effect of the menu on their waistlines. Follow a character as they work, play, eat, explore, investigate, eat, panic, survive and eat at Gerbert’s.

111.content:
The day Vinnie Paulson got the ultimatum his father was coughing and wheezing all the way down the stairs. Mainly from all the fumes from Vinnie’s weed habit.

“Now look,” the old man said. “I am sick and tired of you stinking up the house you lazy bum.”

Vinnie, satiating some munchies with half a burrito, didn’t reply right away.

“You’ve flunked out of high school, got no college prospects, I will throw you to the curb unless you earn your keep.” A set of the classified ads was tossed at Vinnie, who caught it on delay with greasy fingers after it had already landed on his chest.

“If you don’t have a job by tomorrow you’re gone!” The old man wheezed his way back upstairs.

Vinnie exhaled and took a look at the classifieds were stuff had been circled. Office clerk? No. Shipping? No. Mining labor? So far all the jobs sounded hard and sucky. Vinnie slunk further into his well worn groove on a pot and shroom infused couch. Distinct apathy at whether he’d be forced to complete actual labor or be thrown out of the house left him indecisive. He turned the newspaper pages back over.

“Gerbert Gerbil’s looking for new hiring.”

In the dim light Vinnie skimmed over the notice. The space themed pizza joint all the kids frequented? Damn, that didn’t sound hard at all! Maybe he could score some free pizza out of the deal too.

Interviews open. For once there was a different kind of fire lighting Vinnie up.


Despite not having any applicable skills, demeanor, or shirts that didn’t reek of perspiration, Vinnie found himself a job. Greg Pierce, a reedy and jovial kind of guy, lead him through the hiring process, uniform and other tidbits.

“So this is what we in the business call the main Showroom Floor,” Greg indicated after Vinnie had been given a uniform. The checker tiled dining room faced a central stage that housed the main animatronics; Gerbert Gerbil, Hippos Don, Moolia the Cow and Fuchsia the Flamingo. Each table had cheap white paper confetti pattern tablecloth, the booths on the edges having menus while a few tables in the center were set up for a party.

“This is where the show happens. We also have individual party rooms for multiple groups so they rotate between their main party space and coming out here for the show. The key thing to working a Gerbert’s is good knowledge of the space.”

Vinnie was scratching his chin and only half listening. He always got itchy towards the end of his buzz.

“Remember to smile,” Greg said with a plastered grin. “You are the face of Gerbert Gerbil’s!”

Vinnie forced a smile, wisely keeping his teeth covered.

“Now this is Mabel Lynn,” Greg indicated a petite woman, probably no older than Vinnie. “She’s our new floor manager so she’ll be responsible for getting you up to speed.”

“Welcome!” Mabel said with her own smile. Though not a genuine smile, she was cringing at the sight of Vinnie. Greg didn’t appear to notice.

“She’ll be instructing you on all the spaces we need cleaned. Like I said before the key to working here is good knowledge of the space. I’ll be in touch.”

Greg departed with a wave. Vinnie, unsure if he needed to wave back, returned a very delayed wave. A pair of fingers was snapped in his face.

“Now look here pothead,” Mabel said, true colors showing. “I can tell you might not care about whether you keep this job or not. But I care about my job and I can’t have you jeopardize that. So don’t do anything stupid or I will have you blacklisted, understand?”

She reminded Vinnie somewhat of his old man, so he just stayed quiet and nodded.

“Good, now you need to report to…”

1111.content:
Still getting used to the clinginess of the Gerbert’s employee uniform (did they hyper-starch these or something?) Vinnie went through the one employees only door that was indicated to him. Inside the smells were like heaven to his over flared nostrils.

Cheese, grease, tomato sauce, pepperoni, other stuff. The usual smorgasbord Vinnie liked when he and his friends were getting good and stoned. It was a mouth-watering smell. And chocolate cake! There was chocolate cake being baked somewhere too.

“You must be the new guy then?”

There was a rotund woman, not much older than Vinnie, hands deep in a mound of pizza dough. She had a pretty enough face. For Vinnie it was enough that she was female and not snapping her fingers in his face.

“Uh yeah, I guess so.”

“Then welcome to Gerbert Gerbil’s kitchen! I’m Sandy.” Hers was a genuine smile. “Mind passing me that water bottle?” She nodded towards a drink caddy sat on the shelf above her.

Vinnie reached up for it. Upon popping it open he smelled pepsi inside.

“If you could just hold it in front of me.” Hands still caught in the dough, Sandy moved her head to take a long slip from the bottle. “Thank you,” she said after a refreshing sigh, “it gets mighty hot in here sometimes with all the cooking.”

She returned to beating the pizza dough flat. “Hey Jessica, come over here and meet the new guy.”

“Wha?” another voice spoke up from further back in the kitchen. Another woman walked around the corner. The blonde to Sandy’s brunette, she was as short as the manager but had a doughy pear shaped body. Even though she was wearing gaudy oven mitts Vinnie found himself staring at her chunky thighs.

“This is…what’s your name?” Sandy asked.

“Vinnie.”

“Oh, ok. I’ve got cupcakes in the oven,” Jessica said, uninterested. She went back around the corner.

“She’s friendly when you get to know her,” Sandy said. Once she had gotten the dough flattened to the right shape she scooped on some red sauce. “Whatcha here for Vinnie?”

“Uh, that maple chick. I mean, Mabel, told me to come here.”

“Oh, Mabel.” Sandy spoke in a mock whisper. “Yeah, she can be a pill to swallow. But stay on top of your tasks and she won’t bother you.” Sandy clapped her floury hands together.

“We can’t have you cooking in here with all your scruffy hair.” Subconsciously Vinnie ran a hand over his mullet. “So Jessica and I will need you to grab things from storage and the freezer, mostly. Not all the time, just check on us every once in a while to see if we need something. Did they show you where the freezer is?”

“Uh…” if they had Vinnie hadn’t been paying attention.

“It’s just further down the hall. I could use some more ground sausage and chicken cuts.”

“Right, uh, guess I’ll get that.” Vinnie backed out of the kitchen obligated to work. He was hoping he would start tomorrow.

112.content:
“I just, I just can’t be with you anymore.”

“What are you talking about baby?”

Jessica Getty did not need this complication in her life right now. It had been a long weekend and she’d slept in too late, she was late for her job at Gerbert Gerbil’s. Not only was she late for her job she was late on her rent, she was a late graduate because she had to repeat a grade. For most of her life Jessica had been late at things. And she didn’t need her ex-boyfriend calling her this morning.

She was trying to sort out what little bedhead she had while tangled up in the phone cord. “I mean it Jason. Us…we’re not an us anymore. You barely pay attention to me and when you do I’m at work, I can’t have you coming to work like that.”

Her stomach rumbled. Breakfast would have to be skipped if Jason wouldn’t get off the phone. But now he was launching into one of his chauvinistic tangents.

“That has nothing to do with it!” Jessica shouted. She was reaching the end of her fuse. Jason wasn’t picking up any of her hints. “It’s not, this isn’t something out of the blue it hasn’t been fun going out with you for the past few months.”

She didn’t want to yell at him because he would yell back. Although she had reached her boiling point.

“LOOK! Just because we had the horizontal tango didn’t mean I still wanted to be with you! I thought maybe that would let us split up on a high note but clearly I was wrong. I have to go to work.”

Jessica hung up on him. And clenched down on all those bitter feelings all the way to Gerbert Gerbil’s pizza.


Although she was very late to work Jessica managed to smooth things over enough to not get a reprimand. She claimed she was feeling ill. She was feeling sick, she’d been feeling sick ever since last week although that might have been more to do with Jason. Not that Gerbert’s had much of a sick day policy so she was still expected to work.

“Girl, you look dead tired.” Her co-worker in the kitchen, Sandy, spoke up once they were back into their routine. Sandy was a few heads taller and several dozen pounds heavier than Jessica was.

Jessica was rubbing her eyes in-between mixing up frosting for the cakes. “I am tired. Sick and tired, I can’t seem to shake it.”

“Need a break?” Sandy offered. “Cool off in the freezer maybe?”

“Nah. I need my rent money too much to be caught slacking again.” Although Jessica put on an air of hardening her efforts in the kitchen her empty stomach betrayed her with a rumble.

“You need to eat something,” Sandy chided. “I know they don’t want us eating in here but,” she overturned an empty water pail in the corner for Jessica to sit on. “I’ll look away while you eat something. Here, homemade lunch.” Sandy passed Jessica her lunchbox. “Or there’s the leftover pizza. It’s…old.”

“You sure about this?” Jessica glanced nervously at the camera over by the kitchen door. She didn’t need the day shift guard reporting her.

“Relax, its fine.” Sandy lowered her voice to a half whisper. “Actually that camera hasn’t worked in ages. I think the cooking steam shorts out the visual feed. Audio might work so just be quiet about it.”

Begrudgingly Jessica sat down at the makeshift seating area Sandy had set up for her. The main pizza cook was far too kind, Jessica was feeling worthless the way her weekend had been going. To make up for missing breakfast she opened Sandy’s lunchbox.

1121.content:
Appreciating Sandy's generosity, Jessica cracked open the borrowed lunchbox. Goodness, this was well packed! A bologna and pastrami sandwich cut in rectangles. Homemade potato salad. An assortment of veggies, diced fruits, and a bag of chips. Jessica just about inhaled the first half of the sandwich, her mouth salivating at the anticipation of feeding her hunger. She crunched some of the veggies between her teeth, finding a cup of ranch dip and dunking those in before opening the packet of chips.

Garlic taste. Heavily seasoned. Factoring in the sandwich that left Jessica's throat dry. "Do you happen to have any--?"

Before her question was finished Sandy, wrists deep in some pizza dough, extracted a hand to point towards a pair of thermoses. "Left has the soup, right has the hot chocolate. Try not to get them mixed up."

Momentarily hefting herself from the overturned bucket seat, Jessica grabbed the two thermoses. She opened up the hot chocolate for a long chug, then returned her surprisingly ravenous attention back to Sandy's lunchbox, spooning up potato salad.

"Try to save me some of my lunch, you know," Sandy said a few minutes later. Jessica looked up guiltily, her cheeks stuffed with the last of the fruit and quarter of the sandwich.

"Never mind," Sandy sighed, although her tone was sympathetic. "Plenty of options for figuring out my own lunch around here." A pause as she returned to her work. "Again."

Jessica reached for the thermos, finding chicken soup in place of the hot chocolate she had been anticipating. Chasing the soup with the creamy beverage made her notice the dynamics of the savory chicken broth along with the milky chocolate. Glancing to make sure Sandy didn't notice Jessica took a swig from both, eventually draining both from alternating sips as she tried to find the right balance.

"Feel better?" Sandy asked as Jessica was cleaning up the inedible remnants of the lunchbox.

"Loads, actually," Jessica smiled. "Let me wash these up for you." She set aside Sandy's lunchbox near the other dishes to wash, then returned back to her bakery station. Now to finish up those cupcakes.

-gurgle-

Jessica bit her lower lip. Yet another pang of hunger, right after she had taken advantage of Sandy's generosity by eating her entire lunch. It looked like the pizza cook didn't hear that last rumble over the sound of slapping out dough balls into shape. Jessica felt worried. How could she still feel hungry after eating lunch?

She thought back to the argument with Jason. She had skipped breakfast, so maybe her metaphorical gas tank was still a quart short? What else was there easily enough to grab in the kitchen without it being missed?

That's when Jessica saw the old pizza. In fact, it looked like it might not have changed positions since yesterday. Unused pizzas at Gerbert Gerbil's were kept in the food warmer by policy, a set of stale pepperoni and sausage slices having long crusted over to where the cheese couldn't even bubble anymore. Jessica held a long, unfocused gaze with the old pizza before her newfound appetite finally won out.

Okay, eating the stale pizza was tough. At least it was warm, meaty and once you got past the hard surface the cheese gave way to softness underneath. Jessica snuck two slices when Sandy wasn't looking. Which turned into the rest of the old pizza slices over the course of the next half hour.

Feeling rather unaccomplished in her day of snaking, Jessica buckled down harder on meeting the quota of cakes meant for a birthday party later that afternoon. She focused on a familiar rhythm of mixing batter, baking, cooling and decorating said cakes.

Broken up by still more cravings.

Still utterly bewildered by her hunger pangs Jessica was losing all will against them, taking more brazen attempts at sneaking bites now that she had heard the camera in the kitchen didn't work properly and Sandy was the only other worker on shift, herself distracted with cooking. What was the harm with Jessica invoking the rule of the baker's dozen, with a thirteenth (and accompanying fourteenth) cupcake for her to savor.

The followup half bag of buttercream frosting was unintended until Jessica realized she was squeezing the sugary goodness right past her lips. She did remember to start a new bag to continue frosting cakes for the customers.

Overall, just as Jessica thought she could eat no more, her stomach would settle in fifteen or so minutes to offer up a little more room. Maybe it was due to her accidental combination of chicken stock and hot chocolate that had her mind and tongue straying towards downright bizarre taste combinations.

To heck with this. Call it an early supper but Jessica was making herself something to take home. That is, if she could leave work before scarfing it down right then and there.

11212.content:
"Ah, shoot!"

Ignoring her continuous cravings for the time being, Jessica realized how much she had neglected to complete her work. She was under quota on cupcakes, running out of frosting and there was the pile of dishes she still had to wash. Let alone she had just dumped too much cinnamon into the cake batter she was working on, the batter itself having sat out too long.

Jessica needed to shape up. However she took a taste of the batter, liking the cinnamon mixed with the sprinkle cake mix. Company policy said improper cake batter should be wasted but why should that be? The cinnamon gave Jessica an idea. Coffee cake! It wasn't a flavor found at Gerbert Gerbil's and Jessica half remembered a recipe for simple coffee cake.

The real question was where to get coffee. There wasn't any in the kitchen. Then Jessica remembered the staff lounge, making an excuse to step away. The loge had that strange coffee drink machine made from leftover animatronic parts. Few ever used it so there were plenty of coffee crystal containers that Jessica felt one wouldn't be missed.

Back in the kitchen, she got to work mixing in the base coffee component to her batter. She hunted up other spices to add to the mix. A pinch of this, a dash of that, a fistful of brown sugar...

Butterscotch chips? Why not. Root beer? Could work. Gummy worms and marshmallows? The sugary treats were some of Jessica's favorites as her inhibitions got away from her and the core coffeecake idea. All the chunky ingredients were making it hard to mix.

"What have you been working on over there?" Sandy asked, startling Jessica.

"O-Oh, nothing," Jessica had been so caught up in designing her own cake that she had forgotten that Sandy was in the kitchen. "Just an...experimental recipe from corporate," she fibbed.

"Ah," Sandy believed Jessica's answer readily, hanging up her flour caked apron. "I'm clocking off until I come back this evening to close. Don't let the day get away from you."

"Bye," Jessica sighed with relief when Sandy left, some unnoticed tension leaving her body and freeing up her shoulders. Feeling emboldened by what she thought she could get away with at work and still suffering from her mysterious hunger pangs, Jessica continued mixing the batter until it was just the right consistency. Then it was time to find a cake mold and bake.

As she waited for the cake to bake Jessica leaned back, one hand idly reaching for the give of her stomach. She felt kind of bloated from her contest snacking today, a hint of pudge plumping out her middle. Before she started feeling self conscious she got off her duff and tried to tackle her remaining work as her crazy cake was baking.

Later, once it had baked and cooled, Jessica stared longingly at her creation. The cake had turned out far too dark, nearly burnt, although as far as random creations went Jessica was happy that it had kept its shape. Trying a chunk, she was heat heavy with the coffee/cinnamon taste and the end of a melted gummy worm. Although a cake wasn't a cake until it was frosted. Cream cheese frosting was the only way to go, followed up by a caramel drizzle.

Finally, it was time to try a piece.

"Hmm," Jessica chewed it over, factoring the taste and texture.

"Mmm," she smacked her lips, trying to bite through a very chewy section.

"Urgh." It was a very dense cake, very strange tasting but still satisfying for Jessica's sudden shift in appetite. She was starting to reach her threshold, however, and with that drew the puzzle of how she was going to leave with the cake without it being noticed by management. Even if the kitchen security camera itself was on the fritz there was one in the hall right outside, she'd be spotted the moment she walked out with the cake.

112123.content:
As nonchalantly as she could manage Jessica left the kitchen with the excuse of retrieving more frosting from the storage freezer to thaw. In actuality she was looking to where the cameras in the staff only section of the restaurant where placed. Her trip, complete with an outer lap into the main section of the building to remember where the other floor cameras were, ended at the kitchen with quite the puzzle facing her.

Jessica couldn't think of any route out of the kitchen that would allow her to keep her cake hidden. She had to assume the rest of the cameras were still working, unlike the one in the kitchen with its video on the blink. Three cameras were at the staff entrance and branching hallways. The cameras in the dining and playroom were off in the corners but that gave them a wide angle of coverage. Jessica would be seen carrying something cake sized even if it was from a ways off. The real death knell to her take-home plans was the camera just outside the kitchen door. It was a panning camera that would swivel to look down both ends of the hall in turn, although it was directly across from the kitchen door. As the camera cycled through swings there would still be part of the kitchen entrance visible in the corner of the feed.

It looked like if Jessica really wanted her cake, she would have to eat it too. Right there in the kitchen during the remaining time of her shift before Sandy came back to close. The real difficulty was that she had been eating over the course of the day, would she really have the room for it? Jessica wasn't one to let food go to waste, her bottom heaviness hadn't only been from hereditary genes.

With a reluctant sigh Jessica willed herself to eat up the rest of the cake. She couldn't leave any evidence of the forbidden confection for Sandy or management to find. She was beginning to regret having used a 9" by 13" pan.

To help mask the sounds of her eating from being picked up by the camera's microphone, she started the water in the sink again to make it sound like she was washing dishes. Setting up her impromptu bucket seat by the sink, Jessica rattled some baking trays between bites to complete the effect.

It turned out Jessica was just two slices away from her threshold. The short, hip heavy baker felt her stomach indicate it was full after a shift of eating far more than usual for her. She looked at the remaining three-quarters of the cake with disappointment. This experiment was about to backfire on her drastically. The sane mind would have cut her losses by now and thrown the cake away, hiding it under further garbage bags. Yet Jessica couldn't bring herself to do it. Something about strange, bizarre tastes had become addictive for her taste buds, plus cream cheese frosting was one of her favorites.

Solidering on, Jessica worked her way through another column of cake slices. The gooey chips and half melted gummy worms proved to make each bite slow and it only got slower going the more Jessica ate. What had been a warm feeling of contented fullness was giving away to the pained feeling of being overstuffed. Jessica looked blearily at the cake, idling clattering dishes together to make it sound like she was still busy. Half of it left.

Another two pieces and her jaw was starting to hurt from all the chewing. Her face was feeling flush. She'd lost track of time, mindlessly eating in the constant battle against the monstrous cake. The groaning from Jessica's stomach changed from gurgles of hunger to moans begging her to stop.

She soon had to untie the strings of her apron, her middle feeling quite tight. Jessica breathed heavily. She was fit to burst. One lone quarter of the cake remained.

The entire situation had become a sunk cost fallacy for Jessica. She was committed to finishing the cake now, believing it would hide the evidence of her overeating on the job (by more overeating on the job). Just small bites of cake was painful, her stomach protested, and there were two slices left to go. Jessica clutched her tender middle but had to stop as it caused a new flare of pain in her belly. The bucket was not a comfortable seat, her bum hanging over each side, however Jessica had effectively pinned herself from such indulgent gluttony.

One slice left.

Jessica had legitimately run out of room three slices ago. She could feel the backlog of food sitting heavy in her stomach. It felt like it had built up to the bottom of her throat. She was breathing hard, body flush with pain and sweat. The tantalizing random taste of the cake a deadly relief to her pain.

"Oh..." Jessica gently stoked her stomach, trying to find some kind of relief. Half a slice of cake taunted her. "...God..." After a series of short breaths, Jessica squeezed her eyes shut and ate the last of the horrible morsel.

She sat there for far longer than she should have, her legs had fallen asleep. All Jessica could do was lightly moan. Her stomach was so densely packed it didn't budge a millimeter, so densely packed with the densely packed cake. Gripping the side of a counter and the edge of the sink, Jessica laboriously hauled herself up.

Although she was standing now, her stomach felt like it was still stuck below, the lead weight barely able to digest in her belly.

A little woozily, Jessica tried to make do with removing the last of the evidence, plopping her cake pan and silverware in the sink to be washed. It took every effort from her to not fall face first into the sink. She was still trying to finish dishes by the time Sandy returned for her closing shift.

The plump cook thought something was amiss when she came to relive Jessica, although she couldn't figure out what. The young baker was typically a fount of energy, although today she had been sluggish. "You alright, girl?"

"F-Fine," Jessica lied loudly, trying to drown out the angry sounds from her belly. The telltale cake pan was up in the drying rack, nondescript amongst similar pans. It was enough to adage Sandy from further scrutiny, although the cook found it odd that Jessica plodded out of the kitchen with a slow march as she left to clock off.

Just going through the simple steps to punch her timecard made Jessica queasy. She regretted eating all of that cake. She couldn't explain it, being lost in the mindless consumption throughout the course of the day. At the moment she felt that her esophagus was working against her, reversing its tract as the bodily corridor from mouth to stomach. Her stomach was far too full that food was starting to work its way back. Like she was one of those gaudy PEZ dispensers only for sickly custom cake.

Her gastrointestinal organs were currently locked in a truly monuments ordeal. Jessica had stuffed her gullet with plenty of food before she had indulged in her indecent cake concoction. The process of breaking all that food down to unleash more energy was taxing every fiber of her being. The skin along her middle tingled, slick with sweat and feeling confined by her shirt and work pants.

Rest...her body ached for a chance to rest, a chance to sit and digest all she had happened to feed it. The dining hall opened up in her bleary vision. Lights blinked from the stage although the seating was surprisingly empty. Rain pattered away on the metal roof of Gerbert's. Rain. A slow evening. Comforting rain, the sound of rain always helped Jessica fall asleep, especially if life was troubling her. And life was plenty troubling. Jessica had been putting in long hours at the restaurant recently. Then there was her breakup from Jason plaguing her from this morning. She had once thought he was the guy she would always be with...but it was getting harder to think as that feeling of fullness blotted out everything else from her mind.

She just needed a rest. Five minutes to sit down. Jessica sat herself in a booth, overjoyed that she had found one without the busted springs. A small bit of relief entered her, her feet happy to be freed from supporting the bulk of her binging. In the distance, or perhaps it was from her fading consciousness, the sounds of arcade games in demo mode bleeped and blipped and rattled in tune with winking lights out of the corner of her eye. The drowsy Jessica failed to notice how her shirt had lifted a few centimeters, freeing a bit of her bulging belly. She was too stuffed to move from this spot, failing to remember that sleeping on the job, especially out in the customer dining, was frowned upon. Still, the booth was a better fit than the tatty old couch in the employee lounge which almost perpetually smelled like drunk employees.

Sitting herself in the booth was all it took. Jessica was out like a light, thrust into a food coma and dreamlessly sleep.

1123.content:
It was turning out to be a lousy month for Jessica ever since she had broken up with Jason. The stress and how much she’d been working lately must have been getting to her because she felt sick all the time.

Her nose and tongue were hypersensitive. Jessica knew that while Cosmic Crew employees were meant to keep up a modicum of cleanliness standards she hadn’t realized how rank many of the caked in smells to the joint were. Rancid leftovers from the dumpster. The permeation of grease that had seeped into every wall. Jessica couldn’t even look at cracked eggs anymore, which was a problem given that she was a baker for Gerbert Gerbil’s. It was all she could accomplish to no hurl into her cake mix.

Jessica’ illness did not go unnoticed. Well, in actually Jessica hid her symptoms as best she could because the new floor manager, Mabel Lynn, was a skinny witch if there ever was one, she got the last manager fired just from pulling up all of his dirt. So Jessica had managed to swallow down the ever-present bile and mask her health as best she could, from both Mabel and some of the other employees.

Sandy was the one co-worker that knew better, given that both Sandy and Jessica worked in the kitchen. The plumper and slightly older cook wasn’t a nurse by any means but she tried whatever she could to make her younger colleague feel better. All the appreciated efforts were mostly for not as Jessica’s body turned into a sluggish crawl so as to not be violently ill all over the kitchen.

“Are you sure you haven’t got the flu or something,” Sandy asked one afternoon when Jessica’s face had flushed.

“No,” Jessica said. “I only seem to get sick when I’m here.” That was a half-truth. Sometimes it was a bear for Jessica to leave her bathroom when getting ready in the mornings.

“Could it be something with those test renovations? I didn’t think Bilbo having to install new animatronics would cause foreign particles in the air.”

“It’s not that either.” Jessica took a seat on the overturned pail. “It’s just…ugh, I’ve never been sick like this before. Guess I’m quite late for all my colds this year.”

Jessica laughed weakly, it was a poor attempt at a joke. But that got her thinking. And dawning comprehension showed on her face as she did some mental math regarding her biological clock. She was LATE!

A feeling of butterflies added to her stressed tummy. “Can you,” she asked Sandy, eyes boring ahead into nothing but kitchen appliances, “would you mind finishing this batch for me? T-there’s something I need to get at the drugstore.”

“Wish I could but these Extra Cheese Specials can’t make themselves…” When Sandy turned around Jessica had already left. “Damnit girl.”



Though the closest drugstore was a few blocks from Gerbert Gerbil’s it didn’t have public restrooms. Jessica was forced to sneak back into work to use the pizzeria toilets. She waited until some giggling girls returned to their birthday party before using a stall.

Soon she got the results of the pregnancy test. And it was true that she was late. Jessica was pregnant!

113.content:
“Hot pizza coming through!”

Times were busy at Gerbert Gerbil’s Pizza what with a double birthday. Two party days always meant the kitchen was hopping. Sandy, one of the main cooks, could barely keep up with precariously balancing two wide trays with fresh out of the oven pizza, ooey-gooey bubbling cheese on both and crisp pepperoni on one of them.

She could hear the echoes of the screaming kids all the way down the checkered halls of the pizza joint, past the kitchen and prize corner towards one of the private party rooms.

“Who’s ready for pizza?” Sandy asked. A veritable hoard of little kids in their party hats and cardboard animal masks screamed in excited jubilation at the prospect of pizza. She sat down both of the pizzas on the table and they were almost devoured on the spot. One of them already had a piece missing, which shocked Sandy until somebody tugged on her uniform.

It was a little girl in a purple Hippo Don mask. She lifted it up. “Could we get some more soda too?”

“Well aren’t you the sweetest!” Sandy had a real soft spot for kids. Given the crappy hours, the inadequate staffing and poor quality supplies Sandy would have left Freddy’s for a better job if it wasn’t for the delight on the children’s faces.

Sandy bent over, noticing the youngsters pink party dress. “Let me guess, you’re the birthday girl?”

“Yes! I’m finally 8!”

“You’re so cute I could pinch your cheeks,” Sandy said, although she refrained from doing so. “I’ll get some more soda, what’s your favorite? Cola? Mountain Dew?”

“Grape soda.”

“A girl after my own heart that’s one of my favorites.” Sandy could see herself in this little girl. Especially given the snugness of the pink party dress. Sandy had always been a pudgy girl that had grown into a fat young woman, by this point in her life she’d gotten comfortable with that. “Eat up, I’ll be back with more soda.”

Sandy left the party room with a smile on her face. Until she realized where the missing slice of pizza had gone…

All Sandy had to do was step out of the private party room, the fate of the missing slice only a short distance away. She frowned, empty pizza trays held at her hips. “Roxanne, that wasn’t your pizza.”

Roxanne, the hostess, was leaning against the wall eating the stolen slice of pepperoni. “You’re late with the pizza,” the redhead said in her snug white and pink roller-skater alien costume, sans mask. ‘Snug’ because of Roxanne’s exaggerated hourglass figure, lots of straps and velcro tied over her pride and joy; her bosom. “Those kids are supposed to catch an robot sing-along in ten minutes and then circle back to catch the main Cosmic Crew show.”

“That doesn’t excuse you from eating little kids’ pizza,” Sandy countered.

And I’ve got no time for a lunch break so I can take whatever I need too. It’s all going to the same place.”

Catching sight of her mirrored image in a reflective wall panel, Sandy stopped. There was a gooey string of cheese dangling from the corner of her mouth. Recognizing the taste of sauce and pepperoni on her breath she realized she had eaten the pizza slice compulsively without being conscious of the act. A further stomach rumble punctured this revelation.

Unfortunately, it was quite common at Gerbert Gerbil's for the kitchen workers to not get their own lunch breaks in the midst of serving scores of pizzas, cakes and other food. Sandy was having to cover a double shift, Jessica Getty was out with some sort of flu, so she was bereft of any quiet moment to find something for lunch.

Sandy put a had to her mouth with a mollified expression. After slurping up the last of the cheese, of course. How many other pizza slices had she unwittingly eaten over the course of the day? Not only was that unprofessional it was also unhealthy. It felt like working at Gerbert's had contributed to some recent weight gain.

Sandy looked herself over. Her apron and greased stained red uniform framed her plump curves. Most of the weight was concentrated in her belly, as thick as an industrial sack of flour. Her khaki pants were starting to feel a little snug, although there was still room in them. Her hips and backside had fattened to meet the width of her middle and by this point, Sandy's breasts could no longer be considered modest.

Still, who would want to be known as the cook scarfing down on other customer's pizzas? Catching sight of her reflection like that had given Sandy a moment's contemplation as she rushed back to the soda machine to get that grape soda. She could do with losing a bit of weight, At the very least, finding a way of eating healthier so she wasn't tempted to eat the customers' food while on the clock. 114.content:
The worst thing about the job was that Roxanne had to help open the restaurant.

A morning person she was not.

The early hours didn't even make sense for this business. They didn't have a breakfast menu to speak of and the earliest they had customers was after noon. Yet here Roxanne Swank had to be, as early as the cooks and management, to help turn everything on.

"Turn, you stupid thing!" This morning in particular had Roxanne struggling with her junker of a car as she blazed through a red light. A cream Volkswagen Beatle, classic model, that had seen better days. She thought the style of car was cute but didn't have the money for a new model or a proper restoration. The handling left a lot to be desired.

"Same to you, bud!!" Roxanne returned the less than friendly gesture to the guy that cut her off (actually her cutting him off) at the turn into the parking lot for Gerbert Gerbil's & the Cosmic Crew. She parked right by the entrance, space reserved for customers. Eventually the boss would have to tell her to move but Roxanne hoped to be persuasive.

The main problem was that Roxanne's job bridged the divide of cast and crew. She worked as a hostess, of course, but she was also a few of the characters. Usually the alien costume of Bellixie but also two different narrators and sometimes she did puppet shows as well. It wasn't the best start for the aspiring actress. Yet Roxanne was a true thespian, able to keep up her false small for an entire day of guiding patrons, hosting parties and entertaining children.

This pretty much left her pissed any time she wasn't in character.

Already her reputation at work proceeded her, the other mid morning workers avoiding Roxanne as she stomped through the doors. Any newcomer gawkers soon learned that the busty bombshell had a horrid personality. Roxanne was a true stunner, a leggy wide framed hourglass with hefty breasts, vivid dull red hair and a beauty mark under one eye. She liked to pamper herself, bathed in fragrances from a new shampoo or perfume and dressed more fashionable that her paycheck from Gerbert's would suggest.

In other words, a total knockout. She gathered plenty of attention from the male sex regardless of age. From a string of hanger on boyfriends, to being the first crush of some of the young patrons or causing dads, uncles or grandfathers to hold their gaze for too long. As for her fellow coworkers, they knew Roxanne to be as witchy as they come.

"Who used up all the instant coffee?" she yelled from an empty cupboard, breasts swaying from the sudden turn. She got even crankier without the morning caffeine.

"Umm...we're out," mouthed the hip heavy Jessica who paused by the door to the employee's lounge. What the Gerbert's baker didn't say was that she had confiscated the rest of it for some special coffee cake. "But why not use the Decaff machine? That always has java reserves."

"I don't want a cup of joe from...it." Roxanne's issue was not with the Decaff machine. The term was a misnomer as it wasn't only for decaffeinated coffee. It could make regular, decaf, cappuccino and supposedly iced coffee. It had this shape, though, that was off. Somebody had desired to make a coffee machine have some personality with its design. It didn't quite mesh with the designs of the other animatronics in the restaurant, even with the space theme. To Roxanne the sanctuary of the employee's lounge should not have these connections to the rest of the establishment.

"I think it's cute," Jessica said, hitting a switch on the Decaff machine before Roxanne could protest. The vessel within the machine boiled to life. The unit raised up on a set of treads, a robotic arm twisting around to serve the dispensed cup.

Roxanne shuddered. The costumed animatronics were one thing. The Decaff machine both was and wasn't anthropomorphized. It had no true face, although those dials on either side of the 'nose' to the machine that held the coffee pot looked too much like eyes for Roxanne's tastes.

Jessica wisely fled before Roxanne could unload into her. As much as she hated the machine the disgruntled hostess admitted it was a good cup of coffee. Just enough to get her ready for the day.

And what a day it was going to be.

1143.content:
Much to Roxanne's chagrin she was going to suit up in costume all day. The process alone took twenty to thirty minutes out of her day at the best of times. Less if she had help but Roxanne didn't have the friendliest relation with most of her other coworkers. Unlocking the door to Service & Storage Roxanne turned on the lights. All around her were spare costume parts for both workers and the animatronics. Fuzzy displaced parts of the Cosmic Crew were shelved around her, such as Gerbert's torso next to Fuchsia's wings, Moolia's tail and Hippo Don's great purple head, amongst others. Employee uniforms were in the back rack, among with other failed costumed characters.

Roxanne didn't remember seeing any of the spare costumes used. Some of them were animal mascots like Gerbert and the crew, some were decidedly more extraterrestrial. Rows of large black eyes stared back at her she found the means to get into character.

At first Roxanne had relished in the privilege of becoming such an integral cast member. The Bellixie character became an important part of the local Cosmic Crew mythos. Unlike the animatronics, which were prone to breaking down, Bellixie required human input to step into the costume and bring her to life.

Struggling into the outfit most days lessened the high she got from the attention of the role. The costume was effectively a white jumpsuit with pink trim, like a cross between sportswear and an astronaut's uniform. It was quite snug, spandex and velcro making up most of the outfit's material. Once Roxanne was sealed in she could barely breathe. Regulating her temperature was a nightmare.

Next Roxanne had to lace up the roller skates. She had lied about being a good roller skater during the interview, she hadn't skated since she was a kid but soon picked up the skill again within a week. The roller skates helped her get through the restaurant more quickly, often Roxanne would borrow the skates even when she didn't need them. At least the costume wasn't too large and bulky or rollerskating would be a nightmare.

The crowner to the outfit was the mask. Bellixie had the classic variety of wide, inverted teardrop shaped alien noggin with no nose, a small mouth and green skin with huge round black eyes. Completing this look was a series of green tendrils that acted like hair, for lack of a better term, bound back by a pink and white hairband.

When the suit was in place, Roxanne changed from a disgruntled wannabe actress into the giggly, hyperactive alien that was equal parts cheerleader, popstar and the worst parts of roller disco. Such was the result of characterization by corporate committee.

11433.content:
Crrrrrrrrkk...

The tight jumpsuit protested as Roxanne stood up. She felt like a great weight was pressing down on her. "Stupid, *huff* costume!" She tried to flail her arms, the motion slowed by the tension from the tight costume.

It was like it didn't fit anymore. And it wasn't like the costume had shrunk in the wash, these suits had to be specially dry-cleaned. Admittedly the suit had been constructed with an average woman's build in mind, not someone with Roxanne's generous figure. So it had always been snug on her since she first stepped into the role of the alien mascot.

Yet this was weird. Roxanne was struggling to get on the suit. Had corporate swapped it out for a new one? Was this one of the new hire's stupid pranks? The rage was building within Roxanne, a dangerous proposition for the fiery tempered redhead. The next coworker to tick her off was likely to be fried. In her mind somebody was responsible for all her issues this morning.

Not that the unlikely person to tell her would survive the encounter, but maybe it was Roxanne's own fault?

Perhaps she was getting too voluptuous for her own good. Hadn't the other day, she had prided her self on graduating to a new bra size, a feat she hadn't managed since college? Didn't her rear have an extra bit of wiggle? Her hip checking the car door shut had made that guy coming out of the grocery store drop his jaw in awe. Roxanne loved the attention her dangerous curves sent her way. Although she was dangerously close to not minding her figure. That shopping trip had a fair share of ice cream, chocolates, heavy milk and other rich foods in her shopping basket.

Roxanne would never consider herself fat. She was a stunner! All the excess calories were soaked up into her bust and hips, not a hint of pudge elsewhere. A sentiment long overdo for reevaluation.

None of these hints towards some recent weight gain entered Roxanne's mind at all as she fought to put on the Bellixie costume. She grunted, cursed and swore. It was probably a good thing the little kids weren't around just yet, or they'd be getting some colorful bits of language from overhearing Roxanne's frustrations.

114332.content:
"Why," the pained sound of spandex trying to stretch, "won't you," the heavy breathing of the too thick for her own good Roxanne, "close!"

What would have been the gurgle of her stomach, be it from the increased acid production due to frustration or mounting hunger from such exertion, was lost in the stubborn SHAP of two pieces of the costume not wanting to velcro together. Roxanne sat down on a bench in the middle of Service & Storage, utterly defeated and oblivious to the extra pudge on her figure that tried to form a roll as she sat down.

Roxanne was her own woman, so she absolutely hated what she had to do next.

"HELLO?" she called out, "could somebody come help me?"

The response wasn't imminent. Ideas of possible helpers went through Roxanne's head, none of them particularly flattering. Would it be that witchy new junior manager Mabel Lynn? That schlubby guy whose name Roxanne never remembered? Being caught in a state of half dress with the costume, which was so precise that Roxanne had to strip down to the smallest amount of clothing to get in on, was normally a bit of a turn on for the vicarious aspiring actress. Although now, being found so defeated and sweating up a storm from trying to get the costume on, Roxanne didn't fancy becoming the object of barbed insults or leery-eyed looks.

"CAN SOMEBODY help me??" Roxanne called again when her first plea went unanswered. She wasn't about to flash through Gerbert's at this hour looking for help, nor was she going to get redressed to find assistance as that would defeat the purpose.

"Roxanne?" came a small, questioning voice. It was Jessica Getty, the baker Roxanne had wrote off after being forced to use the uncannily anthropomorphic Decaff machine. Roxanne refrained from scowling, as the wide-reared cook was probably the best she could settee for given the circumstances.

"Yes," Roxanne drawled with a faux-friendly tone, "would you be able to help little old me get the rest of this on?"

"Oh, that's what you were doing," Jessica said, entering Service & Storage. "Sorry. I've never been back here before so I didn't know where you were calling from."

Upon surveying the scene of her hostess coworker in the midst of suiting up, Jessica was glad not to be the one that had to strut about in such an outfit. There was something disconcerting about a 'sexy' alien being marketed to kids. Or maybe that was due to Roxanne's own bombshell figure, better than Jessica's bottom heavy genes. Although she didn't want to earn Roxanne's ire by suggesting she looked to have put on a few pounds.

"I need you to bring those flaps together and latch the velcro," Roxanne gestured towards her back the best she could as she continued to lay on the mask of friendliness. "I'm so glad it's you helping me, Jessica, and not one of the guys who might take advantage of the situation."

"Yeah, sure," Jessica replied genuinely but heavily distracted. She wouldn't call herself uneducated but miss Getty had not done the best at school. The most complicated thing she had to deal with her job was setting the oven. The order of operations for closing the flaps, as Roxanne had under-played it, was boggling the mind. She'd seen Roxanne suited up from afar before but Jessica had never comprehended what all went into putting the Bellixie costume together.

As the baker worked on closing up the back Roxanne smelled a hint of cinnamon and coffee in the air. Whatever it was she wanted a piece, although she supposed that would have to wait until she was on break. "I want to thank you again, Jessica, for being so understanding about all this."

"Don't," Jessica wrestled with the straps, "mention it."

Roxanne liked being pampered. She'd settle for having a nobody trying to dress her up as an alien mascot, as it took her mind off of things just the same. "Plenty of people try to help me for the wrong reasons," Roxanne continued, opening up a hair's breadth. "They see my hot bod and think I'm easy pickings as an object of affection, they're always after some perverted goal."

"You don't say," Jessica was only half paying attention, still utterly baffled by how Roxanne had been able to suit herself up before this particular morning when she didn't have the machinations of the back latchings in front of her. Although the hip heavy baker's own love life was not something she'd want to get into at this moment anyways.

"You almost done back there?" Roxanne asked, getting impatient.

"Almost...there..."
114332.title: Some Assistance Please!

1143322.content:
Roxanne was so tired when she sat down that she missed the sound of her velcro tearing from her back yet again. Finally she had some relative peace and quiet in the booth. It was never really quiet at Gerbert's, bloops and bleeps from the arcade could be heard constantly.

There had been a double birthday during the early hours the store was open. For Roxanne, that meant staying suited up constantly. Bellixie had to be present for every animatronic show, photo opportunity and birthday cake presentation. Both sets of families had gone for deluxe packages, which required attention to detail to serve the birthday girls (in today's case) plus a dozen or so friends each that wanted a personalized visit to Gerbert Gerbil and the Cosmic Crew.

For the sole human of the Cosmic Crew it was exhausting work. Once the second party was finished, Roxanne found that there was just an hour or so free of patrons until the expected after school crowd. Hopefully none of the previous sets of birthday guests would make a reappearance. Roxanne had quashed her frustrations with the ill fitting costume for long enough, now that she didn't have to be artificially peppy and cheering.

"Thank gawd," Roxanne sighed when a lunch tray was set in front of her. "Thanks."

"No problem," Jessica Getty said, looking bushed herself as she sat with her own tray. From those two birthdays she had to ice three cakes, the second one needing to be redone because she had outlined the wrong character stencil for the frosting.

"Is that chocolate?" Roxanne asked, surprised.

"Huh?" Jessica was knocked out of her funk. "Oh yeah, chocolate with maple filling. Since I screwed up the second cake, so..." The baker didn't expect Roxanne would go for the cake first, forgoing utensils as she took a big bites out of her corner slice. Smears of frosting covered the hostess's nose and cheeks.

"I swear, those brats don't know cake sometimes," Roxanne relished the taste of the cake. "Those boys kept trying to shove their slices in each others faces. What a fricking waste!"

"Yeah," Jessica agreed. She hated seeing anything she baked go to waste. She tried to motion her hands along her face, to see if Roxanne would notice that she was covered in frosting but Jessica was unable to communicate that thought to the hostess.

"That's the thanks we get dealing with these snotty nosed kids day in and day out," Roxanne angrily bit into her pizza. Lunch had been whatever Jessica could find extra from the catered parties. She had given each of them three slices all from different pizzas, curly fries and carrot sticks. One of the few vegetables Gerbert's served and the kids still didn't go for it. Jessica half felt guilty for her bottom heavy genes so carrots were her go-to side on a meal to pretend that it was healthier.

After stuffing her face for a minute, Roxanne finally swallowed enough to notice that her co-worker was staring off into space. Which for a space themed family restaurant and arcade was far too easy to do. "Hey, Jess? Aren't you eating?"

"Huh?" Caught off guard again, Jessica scratched behind her blonde bob cut hair. "S-Sorry." Her voice was quiet and wavering. She looked down to her pizza glumly.

Roxanne didn't feel like playing big sister but she couldn't stand her lunch being fouled up by Jessica feeling sorry for herself, especially when Roxanne could read the baker's mood all over her face. "Spill it, something is eating at you."

Jessica tried to hold back a sob. "Sorry." She held up a slice of pizza to her lips, although her mind wasn't on eating right now. "I was just thinking about Jason. We've been going out for two years..."

"Uh huh," Roxanne took another large bite of pizza. She could smell drama from a mile away, already guessing what type of issue Jessica would be facing.

"And we were close. And physical, he used to be such a fun boyfriend. I thought he cared. But..." She started to sniffle.

"Oh please," Roxanne leaned over as far as her bust would let her, reaching for some napkins. "Go on. Bow it out of your system."

Jessica cried and sneezed into the napkins. "He...He...but he keeps making fun of me! Whenever I'm clumsy, whenever I get something wrong. And when we last made love he was teasing that my behind was getting too big!"

"Oh please," Roxanne rolled her eyes. "You've been complaining about this guy for how long, Jess?" Roxanne didn't want to dedicate the brain cells to remember how long she had know Jessica, since at least the time she had started working at Gerbert's. "A man that wants more from the relationship that sex wouldn't be criticizing all your flaws, let alone your body."

"R-Really?"

"Really," Roxanne nodded. "So dump his ass already before he dumps you."

Jessica sobbed louder. If Roxanne wasn't so tired from working two parties she would have taken her lunch elsewhere to eat in privacy. She was too exhausted and hungry to move. She did relieve Jessica of some curly fries since her mind clearly wan't on food. Although if she kept crying Roxanne was going to tell her to stuff a sock in it.

Finally Jessica had some intelligent conversation out of her blubbering. "You're right, Roxanne. I've been fooling myself with Jason for so long. He's such a jerk, really."

"Honey, jerks are a dime a dozen," Roxanne replied sagely. "No use crying over them." Roxanne's own overdeveloped bod had awakened her sexual experiences sooner than most girls after puberty. She'd had a lengthy string of boyfriends and exes, all eager to feel up her curves during sex, but Roxanne soon tired of those that only wanted her to put out. She could land any man but most of them were as brainless as they considered her to be, which was their downfall when dealing with a woman with as much personality as Roxanne.

Jessica blew her nose one last time. "Thanks, Roxanne. That really makes me feel better."

"Call me Roxy, Jess," Roxanne said, starting to feel for her co-worker's plight.

"Right, Roxa-Roxy," Jessica smiled and tucked back into her lunch, missing out on the fact that she had far more carrot sticks than curly fries as Roxanne polished off her plate.

"I could go for another slice of that cake," Roxy said, "how 'bout you?"

11433222.content:
It turned out that Roxy's advice to Jess had come at the right time. The baker had confronted her boyfriend about their relationship falling to pieces, beating Jason to the punch as he admitted to wanting to break things up with Jessica.

It brought her much needed closure, although for two days she was distraught and blubbering. Roxanne was her reluctant shoulder to cry on, at first, but the hostess soon took to having the attention from Jessica. Not only did her junior find her a mentor in the ways of love, she also brought Roxy lunch, which was a plus.

Once Jessica was over her boy issues the two found that they had more in common than just working at Gerbert's. Jessica had an appreciation for the theatre, although she had never acted. They watched the same soap operas and liked the same foods. Both of them were thrifty when looking for fashion, as Roxy played mentor again to improve Jessica's wardrobe while the latter had practical remedies to save clothes from stains and wear.

"Shoot!!" Roxy cried out when a glob of mustard landed on her silk blouse. She had paused, mid-fry to her mouth, to chuckle at a story Jessica had about something strange that had happened at the grocery store.

"Oh, don't worry." Jessica reached across with a napkin to mop up the stain. "We can easily get that removed with a vinegar wash. I can bring some from the kitchen to the laundry room."

"Is that all?" Roxy asked amazed, as Jessica's domestic know-how was saving her a mint on her dry cleaning bills.

"Yeah, we can do that before close." Technically the laundry was only supposed to be used for company uniforms and costume pieces, not the fancy personal clothes Roxy wore as hostess. Yet the busty bombshell was mildly corrupting the simple Jessica, who was self-justifying more lenient behaviors at work.

Such as the extent of their lunches. What had started as a way to eat unused food had morphed into treating Gerbert's as a personal kitchen. Their employee discount only accounted for staled food, yet the food that was 'staling' was made extra by Jessica just so the two could continue to cater their lunch breaks.

The food was becoming experimental as well. Who said the fryer couldn't be used for homemade stromboli instead of onion rings? While couldn't the cake maker be used for a rum cake matching the recipe Roxy had read about in a magazine? And so what if nacho cheese was unapproved as a pizza sauce?

Jessica loved the chance to improve her cooking and Roxanne relished the newfound tastes to be had in the fried food. Working at Gerbert's had made the chow boring for the hostess. Jessica had been able to find new ways to spin it. Roxy had gone from thinking that she could always blame Jessica if the two ever got in trouble for unauthorized food to wanting to protect her because damn, this stuff was tasty!

The unlikely pair had been building their friendship around these lunches, and the lunches had expanded considerably. What used to be combo plates had graduated to meal platters, as personal sized pizzas were traded for splitting a medium. Then large. And soon it looked like half an extra large wouldn't satisfy both women, and that was before we talked about the sides like fries, breadsticks and corndog bites!

As their friendship was growing, so too did Jessica and Roxanne grow. For the dumpy pear shaped baker, her weight was settling onto her lower half. Her hips gained a couple inches as her thighs plumped up considerably. Whereas her growing rear had been a point of contention with her ex Jason, Jessica's butt had graduated past that point to grow even more wobbly. The extra cushion meant Jessica sat slightly higher in her seat.

It wasn't just her rear, however, that was gaining a layer of fat. Her belly took on a share of calories, and her arms were chunkier. Jessica's height made any weight gain drastic, as she would be sporting a double chin and plenty of backfat soon if her appetite continued to grow.

Roxanne, in contrast, wore her weight far differently. The curvaceous bombshell with her hourglass body was used to ripening in all the best places as she put on weight. All of this pizza and fried food was knocking a blow to her metabolism, unfortunately. Roxanne had been oblivious to her gain thus far, as she treated the growth of her curves as something of a second puberty, making her all the more sexy.

Yet Roxanne wasn't a ripe hourglass anymore. As the newfound weight settled on her body, one of her assets had outgrown the others to the point that her profile was changing.

Instead of her typical hourglass, Roxanne put most of her pounds into one feature:

"Excuse me."

The bakery attendant looked over the counter. No customers in the immediate vicinity. She shrugged and turned back to the novel she was reading.

"Ahem, miss?"

Yet another voice from nowhere. This weirded out the clerk to no end until she stepped away from the register. There was a short man with thick glasses, dressed in green and brown, who hadn't been seen from the other side of the bakery case.

"Oh, sorry," the clerk said, stifling a bit of a giggle. What a tiny man! She almost could have stepped on him. Her expression was easily portrayed on her face, as the man sighed wearily.

"If I could get an apple turnover, one of your bacon breakfast sandwiches, a lox bagel, a coffee with one creamer and an orange juice?"

She balked at the order. "Who's joining you for breakfast?"

"Just me, miss." Bilbo Dennings pushed his glasses up his nose. "Could you please be quick about it? I'm on call today and I don't have much time for breakfast."

She shrugged off his concerns and set to getting Bilbo's breakfast at a less than hurried pace. Bilbo found a chair to hop up onto. He had curly, reddish brown hair. At his size he should probably watch what he ate more often, given his small frame left little space to keep any pounds. He had a slight potbelly from having to rush his meals. For those that asked what his job entailed they soon heard an earful of it during the time it took Bilbo to give a full polish to his glasses.

He worked at Gerbert Gerbil & the Cosmic Crew. Not regularly, at least that was how the position was originally advertised. Gerbert's was the newest and most technologically advanced in children's dining and entertainment. Most of the infrastructure was dedicated to the mascot animatronics and their mobile platforms, a system that was Bilbo's primary concern. Although this had spread out into other issues the restaurant faced. Whatever hoodoo Bilbo or another worker had triggered there had been a downward spiral of problems at the establishment as of late. Bilbo dreaded the signal of his pager interrupting his time off. He'd had so little time to enjoy his own life outside of work.

So it was with relish and enthusiasm that Bilbo anticipated his breakfast, now more of a brunch given the hour of the morning, to enjoy without having to be called in. The majority of his past meals had been rushed or making use of his employee's discount at the restaurant. Much as he could be abashed about his height, although it made crawling under tight hatches and spaces easier, Bilbo wanted to be out amongst the world beyond Gerbert's. Beyond kids he saw at eye level.

BREEEEEEVVV

"NO!" Bilbo cried, startling the bakery worker that was just bringing his plate. "No, no, no!"

"What's wrong?"

"Bag it up! I'm going to have a confounded working brunch yet again." Bilbo pulled out his pager, dreading the issue he was going to face at work.

123.content:
Most days, Houston felt lucky if he got to stay in the office. A feeling not found in most other workers. For the most part Houston actually liked office work. The corporate offices of Cosmic Crew Entertainment were not the biggest or most successful, although Houston stayed in a carved off little niche since coming to the company. He had to admit, many of the proposed projects were interesting.

Cosmic Crew Entertainment was the brains behind the Gerbert Gerbil franchise, which also went by the same moniker. It got by with the immense marketability potential from the mascots of the original family fun restaurant. Gerbert's hit everything that was popular with the target demographic right now. Kids loved space. They also loved animal characters. And with the inclusion of the arcade and playground it should be a winning combination.

Key word, should.

Because Gerbert's was facing a lot of problems. Anything that could go wrong tended to go wrong at the restaurant, putting reality at odds with the proposed expansions the office wanted to have for the franchise. Which brought us to the point where Houston had carved his niche.

He hadn't earned a big desk yet although the ex-jock did have a small, modest office. He set the marbles of his newton cradle to clacking, the sharp sound helping him think. Houston looked like a guy that worked out or used to. He had played hockey, almost would have tried out professionally if not for a falling out with the recruiter. Still, anything that reminded him of the hard impact of the puck hitting the ice took Houston back, pushing his instincts into overdrive.

Yes, Cosmic Crew Entertainment could be a difficult place to work for. Houston should know, he'd been scratching his shaved chin finishing up a report on past issues he had dealt with this year. He was nearly up to sixty pages.

Not that these issues were small fries by any means. First deliveries to the restaurant would hit a snag. Then food quality was reported low, complaints from customers, high staff turnover. The equipment would break down, the kitchen had to be retrofitted twice, construction crews had to come back to finish jobs that hadn't been don correctly, then the animatronics started to break down. They needed more technicians hired, their single one needed more training, the health inspector threatened to shut them down (--Houston had a note here; Sally Norn was her name, wasn't it? Good figure, easy to sway, might be able to convince her otherwise if he invited her to dinner--) and their utilities were overdrawn.

Honestly, that was just one month and the first dozen pages.

Which really was a shame. Houston knew of several proposed projects in the works that looked interesting. Cosmic Crew Entertainment worked hard to innovate to keep attracting the kids. Such projects included new attractions, additional menu items, further merchandise and even talk of another TV show. But as the old adage in business went, you had to spend money to make money, and Gerbert's was too frequently in the red to make any headway on these new ventures.

Houston sighed, leaned back in his chair. To his surprise he smelled the steam of fresh coffee hitting his nostrils.

"You look like you needed some caffeine, Mr. Tuttle."

"Estelle, you're a peach, you know that?"

"You seem to be the only one who tells me that, Mr. Tuttle." Estelle was the floor secretary although Houston liked to imagine she was only his. Polite, friendly, always anticipated what you needed next. And she had quite a figure too. As Houston watched her leave, clutching the empty tray, he felt quite elevated. And it wasn't from the coffee. It was from watching Estelle's backside sway as she walked, she filled out that pencil skirt quite well. She had a pair of calves that made men wonder how the elasticity of pantyhose held out. And dare he imagine it, the waist of her skirt was looking a bit snug, with perhaps a slight pooch to her middle.

Houston could easily lose himself observing the other females in the office. Mainly Estelle. Doris in promotions wasn't bad either, nice rack, although she was quite the shrew when you were talking with her. This retrospection could go on for minutes.

Until his intercom buzzed.

"Houston--"

"Oh jezus Parsons don't say it."

"--we have a problem."

"Damn you, Parsons." Houston chuckled with a bit of a groan. As if he hadn't been hearing that all his life. And it only worsened when he became employed at Cosmic Crew Entertainment. "What is it now?"

"Hope you're ready for a trip, Houston," came the click back, "they need you out in the field."

"Again?" As said, Houston was lucky to stay around the office. So much for a coffee refill from Estelle.

You know how they say if you find your niche in life, your purpose, you'll do anything to protect it?

What a lousy lesson.

Yes, you've heard the argument before plenty of times in your life. It's one thing for people to say they want to be an artist, an actor, or an accountant. Nobody bats an eye at those choices. But when you get to talking, about your fantasies and passions, everyone gave you a wide berth. Worse, some looked at you with accusation. You learned to laugh, shrug it off. Downplay your intention into a joke, because if you hadn't someone would have done something about it if they had realized you were serious. They would think you a criminal, a lunatic.

But you felt there was nothing to be ashamed of. Once you had been there, that first time, you realized that Gerbert Gerbil & the Cosmic Crew felt like home.

Like it was yours.

Or rather, it was like the childhood you had never had. So many children flocked there, the town came alive when that restaurant was built. All so often, past the fliers around town and the commercials in-between the hit cartoon, you heard about the customers that went there talk about going to Gerbert's. How the mascots moved about on stage, so lifelike. How they roamed the restaurant, delighting the hearts of many. You just had to check it out for yourself.

And when you were there, something clicked.

It was yours.

You *got* what Gerbert's was all about. From the menu, the layout, the clientele and the infrastructure, the whole restaurant fit you like a glove. You felt more alive there than you had anywhere else. Others saw a display to bedazzle that childlike need for whimsy. Others saw a run-down, over ambitious dorky pizza joint with a strange them. You, only you, felt like you could do anything there. And you have.

Done *anything* that is.

But that's putting the horse before the cart in some respects. Launching into your exploits before establishing how you grew into that role.

You were awkward at first, even with Gerbert's to empower you. It took some time before you refined your method. But eventually you found that means of interface. Your exact relationship with Gerbert's.

You stalked the back halls, keeping out of sight of the cameras as you added employee sections to your mental layout of Gerbert’s. A quick grand tour and you had your routes memorized. In the night Gerbert’s was yours.

In fact, you would go as far to say that you were a relief for stressed waitstaff, when kids whined and angry parents were set to raise hell when the elements of their progeny's birthday party were lackluster. You were someone to joke with.

Ultimately your friendliness was a means to the end. Why be burdened with the responsibilities at Gerbert's when you could stay a customer. Food was decent, there was a variety of games at the arcade. Those two avenues were the most appropriate whenever a fresh faced employee was curious as to why you frequented the restaurant so frequently. Still, you'd stay in the back watching a Cosmic Crew animatronic show, even linger out the door of a private party room for too long to catch the routines of the mascots when they traveled the track to a personal visit.

But it wasn't just the restaurant itself that drew your attention...

The people that went there gained your fascination as well. For as much as some of the Cosmic Crew routines, especially the purpose of the 'Bellixie' character played by a staff member in costume, wanted to make sure kids stayed active that was hardly the case. Many more patrons fit the other end of the spectrum. The play pen would be sparsely populated compared to the bodies hunkered down to consume the widespread spread at Gerbert's. You knew how tasty half of it could be and you saw the obvious effects it had on clientele and staff. Besides children, the primary demographic of Gerbert's, there was a hidden second demographic only you seemed to realize.

The establishment attracted fat people.

And that delighted you. From broad hips, full bellies, weighty backsides, full bosoms, tight clothes from the young and old, you liked it all. Each day there were new people to marvel at, new shapes to drive you wild. You started to learn the names of some regulars, bond over a like of the restaurant, allowing you to get closer and offer them the reminder of your purposefully half eaten lunch or save them the steps to get a soda refill. Many of the business crew developed stress eating habits as well, which you offered words of encouragement to lift their spirits along with encouragement to remind them how tasty something on the menu was.

Gerbert's was a fat admirer's paradise. But that alone wasn't going to keep you off the radar. You had to pair your ambitions with something else.
1243.title: Integrated

I am completely alien to relate to.
I have just been here, only in the context of Gerbert Gerbil's.
125.content:
So my story was picked. I doubt it will be much of a story, a narrative to be acclaimed. I'm not much of a storyteller. I can only say what happens, what occurs. All I can do is persist.

And notice things. I notice everything at this place, this building. Where the people come for food, where young ages delight in the games. The walkers in suits, that toil in this place. The one that subverts. I note what means I have to work my influence, impart my will into the world. I notice the tremor behind the joy, the silent horrors, the dreams of broken promises. I notice the dark, melodious sweat that seeps into the walls, I notice the pungent color that masks the true intentions the others keep hidden. I notice the peeling rough taste that saturates the air, hanging thick, cooling the miasma of chaotic sights.

I've worked out a few ideas about this place. It is a happy place. It is a horrid place. It is a place you don't want to look into too greatly. If I were different, I would be content to eat, talk freely, play a game. Tackle this elusive 'fun' that is cornerstone to the concept of this place.

I'm not sure I know what fun is. Or if I ever did.

The past is something I barely recall.

But I hang onto one fragment. When the workings and goings on of this 'Gerbert Gerbil & the Cosmic Crew' get too confusing, I reflect on one frame of reference. Growth. Growth is important. It is what brings changes, it brings betterment. Growth brings a future, a continuation. Growth should not be suppressed, stagnation to be avoiding.

I could be considered an avatar of growth.

But that is only a motive. My origin is much harder to explain, if it can be explained at all. An attempt could still be made.
125.title: What Am I?

choices: I could manipulate technology and the animatronics.
I could focus on people's minds, possessing them and altering their perceptions.
I heard what they wanted, I encouraged new thoughts and desires within them.
1251.content:
I can remember the pain. Not the cause of the pain but the sensation of it. The fatal deadening of nerves. The great change. The Snuffing out. What lead up to that pain I can no longer fathom, or when exactly my consciousness came to in a new state.

People I could recognize. It was morning, sometime after, when they were about the place. Business hours. I went up to them, uniformed workers. There was something important I needed to tell them. But I couldn't speak. When I found the words to say no one heard them. I tried to take one woman by the hand, drag her to a place of importance. I passed right through her.

Concepts of restraint no longer had any meaning for me. I persisted at Gerbert's but no longer dwelled there. I was there but I was also not there. I no longer could interact with people or things. Humans, the living, passed right through. I was unbound by doors or walls. It took some time to regain a sense of time, a sense of continuity.

And with it, something gnawing the back of my identity that something was missing.

Whatever that was, it's hidden or removed some place I cannot find. It most likely is the latter, since I am unbound from any obstruction in Gerbert's. Whatever the case, it was a long period of barely haunting the restaurant before I could understand what I could do.
