13.content:
An animatronic device his a robotic puppet modeled after some character, capable of prerecorded speech and limited movement. Outside of their display platforms they are delicate, jerky things highly dependent on their connection to power and the computers that perform their sub routines.

Oh wait, you were talking about the animatronics at Gerbert Gerbil & the Cosmic Crew.

The animatronics aren't just state of the art. They behave far differently than what's expected for robots, they blend captivating performances with fine motor control and many other purposes. Gerbet's is outfitted with a special track in the floor, usually covered except for special times, that allows the dais for each animatronic to move about the restaurant. They are machines of metal, fur and feathers. Yet they appear so lifelike that many wonder if the animatronics do feel.

What can be said is that after the animatronics were installed they began exhibiting strange behavior. Let alone that there is behavior, beyond their preprogrammed personalities, is unexpected. They were meant to delight children, and the characters are popular to many. Yet there is still something unnerving about them.

Stories within this category are about choice and the extremes of expression. Each Gerbert's mascot as a set personality, determined by cosmic Crew Entertainment to target children demographics, but the animatronics themselves are not the exact same characters. Something has happened to them, or perhaps it was always like this. Maybe their 'defects' are only noticed after hours, or perhaps they have become more pronounced in normal operating hours. In many ways, this is an exploration of how character is created outside of artificial character.

The most notable animatronics are as follows:

Gerbert Gerbil

Gerbert Gerbil is a tawny, brave and heroic astronaut with a mildly outdated spacesuit who explores the cosmos in his rocket ship. As the main mascot of the restaurant and the in-universe stage shows, Gerbert is the upfront leader with his buck toothed grin. While the very face of the whole franchise detractors say his characterization is too generic and bland, nothing out of the ordinary as far as astronaut gerbils are concerned. Probably because no one pays attention to what happens when the Gerbert animatronic is ‘off the clock.’

Hippo Don

Hippo Don is Gerbert’s best friend, a purple reformed gangster hippo that now fancies himself a big shot musician with all the attention he thinks that career deserves. He remixes public domain soundtracks to new wave electronica-disco hits, unbearably cheesy to sit through. Although on the side of good, many of the Cosmic Crew plots are both caused (and paradoxically solved) by Hippo Don’s former criminal connections. Some think is characterization is even better than Gerbert’s and like his funny antics. Although in some perspectives, the gangster may not be that far removed from his pre-musician persona roots.

Moolia the Cow

Moolia is a white cow with pink, blue and yellow spots. Originally a heifer from earth and accidentally swept up in Gerbert’s adventures, several contradictory circumstances have made her alien to her species. She serves as the Cosmic Crew’s manager of the ship’s kitchen and personally endorses the entire restaurant’s menu. The Moolia animatronic is outfitted with special freezers and mixers, able to serve the signature malts and other frozen treats to customers at designated times. Otherwise she has a bubbly and chipper personality that’s often considered shallow.

Fuchsia the Flamingo

Fuchsia the Flamingo is a long necked dancer that seems out of place in the Cosmic Crew. Her usual color scheme is her namesake color with purple and pink accents, much like the flower, although her feathers include fiber optic cables for color changing properties. She was originally pitched to encourage kids to stay active and dance, although is something of a failure in that regard. She ends up being the least developed personality of the Cosmic Crew, in some part pertaining to the misfortune of Fuchsia being the most complex animatronic and thus frequently breaking down. With unusual articulation points, ridiculous choreography routines and the aforementioned color shifting, there’s a stigma of Fuchsia being the animatronic that causes things to go wrong. Yet despite being put in the background she has a cult following of fans.

Hamster Louie

Hamster Louie is a sandy hamster and fellow astronaut alongside Gerbert, a rival ever since they were cadets. At least, that’s the story nowadays. Truthfully Louie is a prototype animatronic before Gerbert and the others, originally meant to be the primary mascot until his characterization was scrapped in favor of newer models. Since then he’s been looking quite thin and shabby compared to Gerbert’s puffier frame, as he lacks critical maintenance and upkeep. The newest trend have been painting him as a villain character looking to discredit Gerbert Gerbil yet always doomed to fail. Although a villainous take on his character may have always been present from the beginning. He certainly has some sort of sway with the various minor animatronics in the restaurant.
13.title: Animatronics

131.content:
"H-H-Hey-y, hey Kids! It's time to blast off with Gerbert Gerbil!" These words were heard at the start of nearly every Cosmic Crew floor show. A chorus of children's cheers proceeded the opening of the curtain to the stage. There, front and center, was the namesake Gerbil himself in his spacesuit.

Although Gerbert was a Gerbil he was nowhere near the size of one. The animatronic was many tens of times larger than the small rodent of his species. With his retractable helmet he was the tallest of the mascots, even able to dwarf most parents in that regard. Only Fuchsia was said to be taller because of her extendable neck, although due to breakdowns that had been bolted back into place.

The music started up for the mascot's signature "Cosmic Crew Fall In!" song that introduced all the characters. With robotic precision the characters went through the programmed routine. For some kids who had never been to the restaurant before it was delightful. Others, the regulars, were starting to tire of the same jokes and lyrics. All the same Gerbert had many young fans. He was, after all, the star of Cosmic Crew Entertainment.

"We h-h-hope to se-see you back real s-soon!" Gerbert waved goodbye with an iconic buck toothed grin as the curtain fell on the show stage, signaling the end of the fifteen minute show. While the crowd of children could be heard dispersing to the game corner or turning back to their meals, the backdrop behind the show stage lifted up. The dais of each animatronic moved back on their tracks to their maintenance stations, where a blue suited technician was talking to a much shorter, chubbier fellow.

"God damnit, what keeps making that stutter?" said the technician, angrily clearing his throat as he was immediately on Gerbert to open up a side panel under his helmet.

"I'm starting to think its the actuator," said Bilbo Dennings, the restaurant's main technician. Truthfully the only employed technician, as the company didn't consider hiring anyone else full time. Although there was too much on the little guy's plate with the constant work needed for the animatronics.

"Like that will affect the voice box," the temp scoffed. In truth this was his third call out to the Gerbert Gerbil & the Cosmic Crew restaurant. And it was definitely going to be his last. As he sought to find the right access panel there was a sudden jerk of Gerbert's eyes his direction.

It was a good thing the backstage was soundproofed, given how much the temp technician swore from the surprise. Bilbo tentatively removed the fingers from his ears.

"All of them are damn creepy, that's for sure," the blue suited man spat. "Sooner I get paid the better."

Bilbo sighed. Yet another mechanic to wash his hands of the place. The short man had been hoping for a lunch break but he could sense that he was going to have to do most of the work on Gerbert.

Before his next scheduled appearance the two technicians did everything they could think of to fix the stutter. No dice, ultimately. The origin of Gerbert's stuttering voice box remained a mystery in what little time they had. Hopefully it wouldn't get worse. Bilbo could already imagine the comments to be had about the glitch.

Throughout it all Gerbert just stared. He was an animatronic in low power mode. He could only stare.

Right?
131.title: Gerbert Gerbil

choices: Michelle soon gets annoyed from how close Gerbert travels to her.
What is the night like from Gerbert's perspective?
The night passes without incident, although Gerbert acts even more strangely.
1313.content:
The Gerbert Gerbil's establishment was a very different place at night.

The whole building was empty and dark, with only the night guard on duty. In the dark the arcade and game machines were monoliths, a low electrical hum heard in some places. When the building was this empty any sounds tended to echo across each room and hallway. Everything was shut down and closed.

*vvvrrrrrrrrt-*

Well, almost everything.

"H-H-Hey-y, hey Kids!"

Slowly, Gerbert was on the move.


Michelle Neith was disgusted with her luck. Here it was, supposed to be her weekend off but she had to fill in on the night shift. Douglas Stolz had come down with some sort of stomach flu and there was nobody else to step in for the night shift.

"Ugh!" It didn't help that the night watch was two kinds of annoying. Dull and stuffy. Rarely did anything happen, the need for security was just the company's paranoia. Even if burglars from rival companies got in, how would they ever manage to cart off one of the animatronics? The giant machines were clunky, utter beasts to move when they weren't on their track.

"Would it kill them to leave the air on overnight?" Michelle itched at the tight collar of her indigo and star speckled security uniform. Budget cuts would be the likely answer she would get if she made a compliant. Stale air did little to make the uniform more comfortable. Michelle was starting to worry that the pants were starting to chafe between her well built thighs. She had quite the set of hips but at least she was fit. Mostly fit, She didn't have the metabolism of her teenage self, although the appetite remained.

The security booth she sat in was boring, nothing to do but watch the uneventful camera feeds. True, she cold look back over footage from the day's operations but there were no incidents to report on. All the power left on overnight was for minimal systems, she couldn't anything like turn on an arcade cabinet to find something to pass the time with. Much to her chagrin, all she could do was sit here and snack.

It was no surprise that night shift had a notorious reputation for midnight snacks. Make that midnight to morning snacks. The guards could bring their own and it was an unwritten 'benefit' that after hours employees could help themselves to anything staled out in the kitchen refrigerator. Much as the day shift could get annoying Michelle was a woman who needed action. She was tough, scaring kids and parents with poor attitudes alike. There was literally nothing to do on the night watch.

And that was when she choked on her doughnut when the introductory catchphrase of Gerbert Gerbil himself echoed throughout the restaurant.

"What the--" Startled, Michelle rose out of her slouch to set the camera feed to backstage. She counted the deactivated animatronics. Hippo Don, Moolia, Fuchsia...crap, she had skipped over Gerbert. Because he wasn't there. Utterly confused she accidentally knocked over a binder as she panned through the camera controls, trying to find any footage of the mascot gerbil astronaut inside the restaurant.

"Gotcha!" Michelle huffed. There was Gerbert heading down the hallway towards the private party rooms on the other side of the building. The animatronics legs moved through a limited walk cycle. The motion came from the track underneath Gerbert's dais. "What is he doing down there?"

Just as Michelle was about to get up and investigate, she noticed a memo that had fallen out of the binder she had toppled over in her surprise.

To the Night Watch,
I wanted to warn you that because of the deep maintenance cycle I have set up to try and flush glitches out of Gerbert's programming, the animatronic may run through scheduled routines during the night hours. I'm not sure how many cycles it will take for the system to reboot. It should only be Gerbert that is set to wander through his routines. I apologize for the inconvenience. Make sure that the animatronic faces no obstructions along its track. If the warning lights don't come on please be cautious around the floor track in the animatronic's vicinity, same as how we warn customers during business hours. Please report any glitches or strange behavior you observe in Gerbert's reboot cycle.

Thank You,
-- Bilbo Dennings


Michelle groaned as her nerves settled. Great, now she was going to have dorky Gerbert roam the building on his preprogrammed routines. That little munchkin Bilbo was going to owe her for the added tasks to her night watch!

Still, she supposed it was a break from the monotony of the graveyard shift. After putting Bilbo's memo back in place Michelle checked the cameras again. There was Gerbert inside one of the party rooms, waving to a table devoid of children.

"Stupid machine." Michelle looked for the other half of her doughnut, cursing when she discovered it had rolled under the desk.
1313.title: Later, much much later that night...

132.content:
"Hey ya'll, if you want to catch the next Cosmic Crew bash there's only a minute to find your seats!" Hippo Don's voice boomed out over the restaurant speakers. The call to an animatronic show created an excited change in the young patrons, eager to watch the show from the main hall.

As everyone nestled into their seats the curtain partially opened, shining a light onto the big purple hippo himself. Hippo Don was a bulky figure, dressed in a yellow coat along with red and white futuristic looking shades. His arms motioned over the synth moved out on a platform in front of him, really a dummy prop to coincide with the changing music.

"Let's hear some noise, audience!" For a hippo Don could really ham it up, especially for this style of show lead in where Hippo Don basically stole the show until he was chided by the other animatronics.

"Let's hear it for the main event, my friend, the heroic astronaut himself Ger-bert Gerbiillllllllll!"

""H-H-Hey-y, hey Kids! It's time to blast off with Gerbert Gerbil!" Gerbert Gerbil emerged into the spotlight with an iconic buck toothed grin.

"And we've got Moolia the Cow and Fuchsia the Flamingo," Hippo Don continued, steamrolling into the next set, "But you should know everyone by now. Let's get to the jam!"

"Uh, Hippo Don, s-some in the audience might be here for their fist time." Gerbert scolded. "W-we should have a proper introduction for the ladies."

"This is one of my favorite jams, recorded and remixed and performed by yours truly!" Hippo Don continued unimpeded.

"Hippo Don!" Gerbert chided, while Moolia and Fuchsia were made to look cross.

"Let's see if anyone out there can guess the song!" Hippo Don left room for the din from the yelling kids, while Gerbert's eyes swiveled around perplexed. Regardless of the songs suggested by the crowd Hippo Don continued with his renegade set.

"Don't you know it! It's time for some fresh grade jams in here! Get your hands together for my song..."
132.title: The Rotund Remixer

choices: Vinnie and Sandy start using Moolia for treats more frequently.
Moolia starts dispensing something rather strange.
When Moolia breaks down the milkshake bandits have to cover their tracks.
133.content:
"Oh no, the asteroid creeper has Don!" Moolia knocked her hooves nervously together as the footage cut to her Cosmic Crew shipmate, Hippo Don, being swung about by a tentacle emerging from the impact crater.

"AAaaaAAAaaaAAAaaa!" Hippo Don yelled. "Somebody drop the phat beats on this thing and save me! I'm about to loose my cookies!"

There was a shrieking cry as Fuchsia the Flamingo came onto the screen in an action pose, fight lines radiating around her. She was about kick the tentacle to free Don but she was snatched up too by the asteroid creeper's clutches!

"Oh no, the asteroid creeper has Fuchsia!" Moolia exclaimed, with the same motions as before.

Gerbert Gerbil crouched upon landing as his jetpack shut off. "We have to get our friends out of the asteroid creeper's clutches, Moolia! Or we're going to be in a jam!"

"Jam?" Moolia's pink spots glowed brightly. "How is jam going to help us?"

"You're right, Moolia, jam is too sticky. What we need is something slick. GAHH!"

"Oh no, the asteroid creeper has Gerbert too!" Moolia cried.

"Moolia, you need to do something or the asteroid creeper will have all of us!" Fuchsia cried, as all other members of the Cosmic Crew were seen being flung about by different tentacles in their respective craters.

"Yeah Moolia, like I said!" Gerbert shouted. "We could really go for some Cosmic Crew blue slush right about now!"

"Oh, right!" Moolia struck a pose. Her blue spots glowed vibrantly. After she charged up power, a thick blue stream shot out of her udders. The blue wave splashed over each Cosmic Crew member. The fluid made them slippery enough that they fell out of the clutches of the asteroid creeper. There was an alien shriek as the tentacles withdrew into the craters.

Gerbert stood up, shaking the blue slush off of him. "Thanks for saving us, Moolia! I guess the asteroid creeper couldn't handle the cold."

"Ugh! I feel horrible." Both Hippo Don and Fuchsia were collapsed against each other, each seeing stars and patched up with bandages from the last time they had been seen.

"Don't worry, I'll have you fixed up with an iconic Cosmic Crew malted milkshake!" Moolia said. "These malted milkshakes are an excellent source of calcium!"

Once again frozen desert shot out of Moolia's udders, only this time topping off each of the malted milkshake glasses the Cosmic Crew had not been holding in the previous shot. There was the tri-split cut of each wounded Cosmic Crew member drinking down the restorative malted milkshake.

"That's great, Moolia!" Gerbert exclaimed as Hippo Don and Fuchsia struck revitalized poses behind him. "It's a good thing we had those medicative procedures programmed into your spare parts!"

"Parts?" Fuchsia asked, confused. "Moolia is a cyborg? I thought she was a mutated cow!"

"I thought she was infected with the Nutritious Drinks Space Disease." Don added.

"Yes!" Moolia said as the tri-colored cow struck a cute pose, not confirming any of the possible explanations for her squirting frozen desserts. The Cosmic Crew shared a good laugh as they hopped back on their spaceship, blasting off into the end credits.


"Man, that is one weird show," said Vinnie Paulson, shifting on the couch as he scratched his mustache. He took another hint on his blunt. "Most of the episodes have Moolia shoot something weird out of her udders."

"Aw common, I think it's funny," said Sandy Helder, motioning for her share of the joint. As she leaned over her gut almost toppled over the popcorn bowl.

The weighty pair were sunk deep into the staff lounge coach, of which there was barely enough room for their snack bowls with their combined mass. There was an unseasonal heat wave in the county, most of the usual child clientele was down to cool off at the town pool. Most of the staff had left for the door without business, with only a few like Vinnie and Sandy staying on. Vinnie, since he had started, took it as yet another time to light up on the clock without getting reported by Mabel Lynn, the manager. Sandy had offered the idea of watching the old Cosmic Crew cartoons on tape that the restaurant had stacked in the back room.

Vinnie had become a bad influence for Sandy, a pleasant girl who worked in the kitchen, after he had introduced her to his friend Mary Jane. Now even the kind and caring cook was eager for any time Vinnie was sharing pot. And with getting stoned came hella' munchies for the big eaters.

"They used to show these cartoons a bunch over the televisions back when the animatronics were getting installed," Sandy said as she exhaled her drag. "The kids like them."

"Hmm." Vinnie took back the blunt. It might have been the affect of watching cartoons while high, because Vinnie was starting to have strange fantasies about Moolia's udders.

There was the crinkle of chip bags as Sandy hefted her bulk closer. "You know," she said in high spirits, "the Moolia animatronic can do the same thing."

Vinnie coughed hard. Once he managed to catch his breath he choked out a reply. "No shit?"

Sandy hefted herself out of the well worn couch groove. "Yeah. Its a protocol saved only for private parties with the deluxe party package. Moolia will travel to your party room and dispense your frozen treats herself. Kids eat it up."

To the less drug-addled mind this would be questionable feature for a children's animatronic filled restaurant. But damn if Vinnie wasn't having several pleasure centers crossed in his mind.

The Moolia animatronic shared little with her animated derivative apart from the color scheme, a white heifer with pink, yellow and blue spots. Some of this was due to the fluidity of the animation, where cartoon Moolia had wider hips and prominent udders. The animatronic didn't have the same proportions although the udders were still sizable, if not as obvious. Vinnie had never imagined they were functional.

"So how does this work?" he asked.

"There's a switch on her back to get her in vending mode," Sandy said, trying to reach around. "Provided her tank is topped off from her refueling station."

"Refueling station?" Vinnie had no clue about any of this in the time he had been forced to find a job at Gerbert's.

"Come on, get your cup ready," Sandy nudged him, as the Moolia animatronic changed modes.

"Ready for dessert?" Moolia said in the same bubbly voice as the cartoons.
133.title: Moolia the Cow

choices: Fuchsia continues to break; other fill ins for her characterization are needed.
Fuchsia goes off unprompted in a restaurant visit.
Fuchsia breaks into pieces, leaving her to be hastily rebuilt.
134.content:
"Say kids, d-did you know that each planet has a different grav-v-vity, the force that pulls you down?" Gerbert Gerbil told the audience in the midst of a show at the restaurant.

There was a pause for any response from the children. "Boy, gravity sure is strange on our travels through the cosmos." Hippo Don chuckled. "Isn't that right, Fuchsia?"

The flamingo mascot was meant to respond at this point of the stage show. Instead of her prerecorded line, there was just a buzzing error sound.

"You said it," Moolia said at the designated time, the show routine oblivious to Fuchsia's missing line. "Why, on some planets gravity is so weak you can bound into the air!"

At this point of the show Fuchsia was meant to unfurl her neck and limbs to their full length, to simulate loose gravity. Instead the Fuchsia animatronic contorted, the articulated parts scrunching together past the limit they were supposed to compact. Odd, grinding clicking could be heard from the strain of her motors.

"And on other p-planets, grav-vity is so strong that it-t squeezes you d-down." Gerbert continued. Yet again Fuchsia did the exact opposite, like a released spring her neck bounding up and lolling to one side, her magnificent beak unhinging in an unnatural way.

"Boo!" cried some of the kids in the audience, less than impressed. A few laughed.

"Gravity sounds like a great way to lose weight," Hippo Don joked. "I just have to go to a planet where I would weigh less!"

"B-But your mass doesn't change, Hippo Don," Gerbert chided. "Your w-w-weight is determined by gravity's pull on your mass. You can g-gain or loose mass all the s-s-s-same."

"Shucks!" Hippo Don exclaimed. "Oh well, how about a jam then?"

What followed was an embarrassment to animatronic musical entertainment. Fuchsia was meant to factor into a song to teach kids both about gravity and managing their own 'mass.' Given her difficulties during the show, her lyrics were all choppy and mistimed, if they hit the mark of her fellow performers. The jaunty tune from the other main members of the Cosmic Crew was almost drowned out by Fuchsia's breakdown, beak unhinging all the worse as it flapped about. Her fiber optic feathers went through the entire color spectrum in a random pattern, white to yellow to her namesake fuchsia to green to blue back to white black red orange purple and so forth.

"C-Come back soon for another Cosmic Crew show!" Gerbert waved at the end of the song, the animatronics falling back as the curtain closed. A show that was going to be postponed, the delay coming from some routine that didn't feature Fuchsia heavily was looked for in the programming. Meanwhile kids chided the breakdowns and stupid nature of Fuchsia's performance.

Such was a common occurrence to the most ambitiously built animatronic, prone to the most glitches.
134.title: The Broken Bird

choices: Hamster Louie has bit appearances cast as the villain.
At night Hamster Louie becomes the most active, and the most unusual.
There are other minor animatronics that see Louie as their de facto leader.
135.content:
"Yayyyy!"

Distant, happy screams of children punctuated a concluding Cosmic Crew show. A show where the animatronic mascots sang and danced, told jokes, entertained the kids. Soon the animatronics would depart the backstage, the track taking them to photo opportunities or party appearances. Occasionally they would roam the restaurant as well to be sighted by other children going about their day of fun at Gerbert Gerbil's.

Attention. Audience. The awe of young minds. All devoted to the four main flagship mascots.

And while Gerbert, Hippo Don, Moolia and Fuchsia were lavished with this attention, there was another. A semi-forgotten animatronic. Hamster Louie.

Hamster Louie was left in the dark most times. A shabby looking hamster animatronic, his fur decrepit as it wasn't of quality material, his spacesuit archaic and old fashioned. His mechanical parts were more crude.

When it came down to brass tacks, as far as household pets were concerned there weren't that many differences between gerbils and hamsters. Both were small rodents with many varieties, the domesticated ones easy to take care of as an early pet. As far as demographics go hamsters were quick breeders with a population lead over gerbils. At least that's part of the reasoning when the idea of a space themed animatronic restaurant was first pitched, as the concept needed a recognizable character to draw the children's attention. Something cute from earth, like a little fuzzy pet, made into an astronaut.

Hamster Louie was that proof of concept. A posable, talking, expression making puppet powered by robotic parts. A little herky-jerky in his motion but that was to be expected as a prototype build. Something to entice investors, to display at the starting restaurant while the second model was being built.

Yet there was a change during the design process. The how and why has been lost to time, only that when the restaurant opened it wasn't Hamster Louie headlining the show. There was a new mascot. A sleek, well-furred astronaut in a shiny spacesuit. Gerbert Gerbil.

The rest of the mascots, other animatronic characters, were built around their roles at Gerbert's and how they factored into the show's story. Gerbert's story. Leaving Hamster Louie, the first, the original, to be nigh-abandoned.

Whoever didn't think something like an animatronic could experience jealousy was going to be in for a rude surprise.
135.title: Hamster Louie

choices: The Alien Bots: AV, FM, RC & SX
Suigs and Heev
The Rejects: Gumball, Casino & Decaff
1353.content:
Hamster Louie may have been a forgotten character, an unspoken figure in the Cosmic Crew mythos that received no mention amongst the cast and crew, although that didn't mean he didn't have influence. The other animatronics were locked into routines. Of course they were, they were robots. There were designed to fit a certain niche, programmed for certain actions in the name of entertainment.

Limitations that Hamster Louie didn't have, left to himself. Louie knew how to stalk the unnoticed places, how to travel along tracks that had also been semi-forgotten. Perhaps it was a glitch, or lack of an update since he was a prototype animatronic. Maybe it meant something else entirely. But Hamster Louie was brewing up schemes for vengeance, vengeance against Gerbert and his friends who had stolen the limelight, and vengeance against those that had decided to scrap him.

Attitudes that somehow helped Hamster Louie bend other, lesser animatronics to his will. Less advertised then the iconic Cosmic Crew, there were other overlooked characters, robots, props and rejects. Ones that could be tasked by Hamster Louie for his nefarious plans. The denizens of the space themed restaurant.

Such as the Alien Bots. Four alien shaped robots devoid of any costume or characterization, stated in different corners of the stage show and restaurant. Each only carried a two-letter designation. AV, FM, RC, SX. To the uninitiated the designations were meaningless. However each Alien Bot carried backup tech that controlled aspects of the multimedia uses at Gerbert's. AV for the televisions, video and cartoon displays. FM for the audio, music and sound effects. RC for toy, puppet and moving feature control. And SX for special effects, lights and lasers and sparklers and other elements used for the shows.

Two other interactive characters were Squigs and Heev. Squigs was the multi-tendriled alien thing that zoomed about the ceiling track supported by a tiny spaceship. Squigs was used to deliver prizes and presents. Heev was a clunky creature of metal, orange and tan, containing a helium tank and able to blow up a variety of balloons.

There were also the Rejects. A collective category for the non-spaced themed robotic units for other concepts not originally meant to be at the Gerbert Gerbil's restaurant. Staff had a nickname for each of them: Gumball, Casino, and Decaff. Gumball and Casino are the most similar, being mobile machines. To wit Gumball is a dispenser for namesake gum balls and candy, while Casino is a demographic inappropriate video slot machine. Decaff is quite unusual, being an ambulatory coffee bar with limited expression. Decaff keeps to the employee lounge while the rest are seen on the floor from time to time.

Left to their own devices, these various animatronics and robots are not malicious nor benevolent. There's little within them to act out of their defined role. That changes when Hamster Louie sways them into devious aims.

So which group was Hamster Louie using for a plot?
1353.title: And the Rest of Them

14.content:
Before the breakdowns, the frights and the horrific direction that Gerbert Gerbil's now finds itself in, the restaurant considers its target demographic to be of the utmost importance. The children. For those in their single digit and early double digit years, Gerbert's is meant to be a place of wonder and imagination. Where children come both everyday and at special events, where they play and gather. And ultimately, eat.

Stories within this category explore what it means to be a child. Of the disconnect between the innocent perspective and the unfortunate reality, of how children can be wise beyond their years yet prone to misinterpreting what is in front of them.

Brit Tanner
Age: 10
Hair: Sandy blonde, short

Brit comes from a well off family and tries to be friendly to the other neighborhood kids. But even for her young age she already has high standards and wants perfection. She has a state of the art collection of Gerbert’s merchandise, most importantly toy figurines of each character. These are kept in a Hippo Don backpack, she finds she likes overstuffing it.

Courtney Chiu

Courtney is round faced and quite chubby, the youngest in her family of aged parents and older siblings that have already gone into their own careers. 14.title: Children

choices: First off, something to eat! She's hungry.
Go show up her 'friends' with how special she really is.
Brit comes across a new prize she must have!
141.content:
"No fair!"

Just as Brit Tanner entered the Gerbert Gerbil & the Cosmic Crew restaurant her so called 'friends' had already left her to go play, when Brit was still struggling with her backpack. Well, that was mostly Brit's own doing. Her Hippo Don backpack, the purple hippo with his 3-D specks and yellow rain slicker, was looking mighty stuffed. Brit just had to go everywhere with her stuff, especially to Gerbert's, because she had all of her favorite toys in here, of which she was trying to reorganize when that left her abandoned in the main dining room.

"Who needs stinkin' friends," Brit badmouthed as she rearranged her Gerbert, Moolia and Fuchsia figurines. The young girl may have not realized just how her personality could be off putting to others. Brit Tanner had standards. Everything had to be just right. She needed to have all of her Gerbert's toys with her when she came to the space themed restaurant with the animal mascots. Her food was to be just hot enough, with her favorite soda, and she had to win a new prize whenever she was here.

No other kid in town could match Brit Tanner's collection of Gerbert's merchandise. Or if they did, they didn't flaunt it around the way she did. Brit adored the Cosmic Crew, owning everything from the toys, plush animals, t-shirts, clothing, cutlery, various knick-knacks and all of the cartoon episodes taped. It helped that Brit's parents were rich, richer than anybody around here at least, and she'd been spoilt from an early age to get whatever she wanted, expecting the best when she did so.

Traits that made the other kids view her as a snob. While Gerbert's had become a favorite after school hangout, one that Brit would announce amongst her peers for the attention, no one ever took her up on her 'invitation.' Sure, they would come but they wouldn't come with her, not to hang out with Brit Tanner, leaving her dropped in the vicinity like a used napkin.

Which often left Brit insulting her own generation whenever the other kids wouldn't spend time with her. "Serves them right if I have a fantastic time and they don't," Brit said to herself as she smoothed out her white skirt and pink Fuchsia t-shirt. Anything Fuchsia related was high status amongst the elementary school crowd, or it should be, because of how the animatronic in chronic disrepair rarely had any of her own merchandise. The other kids were too plebeian to notice, to borrow an adult term.

"Why mother insists I need more friends anyway," Brit asked her Gerbert and Moolia figurines, last to be propped up in the zipper portion of the backpack. Posed in such a way that when she wore her backpack Brit's most treasured figures would look over her shoulder to see how much of a good time she was having.

That she spent the first part of nearly every visit complaining about her 'rotten' friends spoke to how much fun she usually had.

Well, Brit was plenty independent. As she readjusted a Cosmic Crew hair clip in her blonde tresses she set out to spend an afternoon at Gerbert's just the way she wanted.
141.title: Little Miss Prissy Pants

Mental challenges
Can't Brit have her parents buy the Gerbert toy for her?
1413.content:
Brit usually went about the Gerbert's establishment in a regular cycle. If she didn't have to visit the bathroom upon arrival she would first see how things were in the playroom, If the lines for the crawl tunnels or slide or ball pit were too long then it was onto the arcade. There were several arcade games she liked, either because they were easy or they were a prime source of tickets. Tickets which she saved up for prizes at the prize counter. And after that circling back to the main room for something to eat. Preferably the ooey-gooey breadsticks, while she watched the animatronics perform a stage show.

The attempted routine hit a few snags this time. When traveling the hall to the playroom Brit was almost run over by someone on the kitchen crew in a mad dash to get a pizza off to a private party room. It made Brit pout. Her birthday was still ages away and she didn't know of anybody with a birthday who hadn't invited her! And then in the playroom two boys had been thawing orbs from the ball pit at each other, other kids caught in the crossfire. Like Brit, as she shrieked and ducked, arms over her head so neither she born her beloved toys would get smacked with a ball. A security guard was hoofing it to break up the commotion.

With a huff she emerged in the arcade, kicking a wayward pit ball back towards the rowdy kids. She needed a moment to recheck the contents of her overfilled backpack, setting it up on a prize display case as she double checked and triple checked everything.

And that was when she saw it.

Standing in a private display case was a toy of Gerbert Gerbil. Not just any toy, because it was a toy Brit hadn't seen before. It was almost authentic to the regular animatronic in a small scale, yet that was only the beginning of its features displayed on a nearby poster. The astronaut gerbil was in an improved version of his spacesuit, it looked like, with buttons everywhere that made it do different things. One cycled his helmet through opened, closed, and reflective layers. Another caused the lights on his suit to light up. Ones activated different functions on his space pack, like pop out jets or the hiss from the pressurization nodule. Another set of triggers activated punch and kick actions with Gerbert's limbs. And finally (so many buttons!) ones that spouted Gerbert's noted catchphrases. All while grinning even bigger with his trademark buck teeth.

Like a child at Christmas Brit went up to the toy and tested a few buttons.

"I'm Gerbert Gerbil, heroic astronaut!"

"Always have fun with the Cosmic Crew."

"Going farther than any gerbil has gone before."

Brit was giddy with glee as she went to get her stash of previous tickets. "How many tickets do you trade for the new Gerbert toy?" she asked the lady at the prize counter.

"None," came the bored reply.

You might as well have told Brit the Easter Bunny was dead. "No tickets!!"

"Nope, Gerbert here isn't won with tickets."

But this was the prize counter! Everything here which Brit had at least one of if not two or four of was gotten with the tickets earned in the arcade games. Dangling a prize you couldn't win with tickets right here should be against the law. The toy was unique! Yes, Brit still loved her own toys but her regular figurines of the Cosmic Crew were barely posable. The new Gerbert toy was dynamic and cool!

Noticing how much Brit was fuming, the lady at the prize counter said, "He's a special prize for the winner of a contest we're going to have at the restaurant."

"Contest?" Brit parroted, some of her dashed hope returning.

The prize counter lady rolled her eyes, having gone through this same spiel a few times already. "All you have to do is win a set challenge and the toy is yours."
1413.title: With Karate Chop Action!

An eating contest.
A dance-off hosted by Fuchsia the Flamingo.

"...we're holding it this weekend," the prize counter lady concluded. Overhead a many tendriled alien puppet named Squigs went off to deliver a present, supported by the flaying saucer that went along a ceiling track.

Brit looked longingly at the Gerbert toy one last time, then down to her watch. It was a fancy watch that told her the date behind the hour and minute hands (except when it was 9:45). Three days. Brit would have to tough it out for three more days to work on her game strategy. That toy was going to be hers! No if ands or buts about it, if Brit was going to have to go through all that effort it was because the only proper end result would be her succeeding. A super cool one of a kind Gerbert Gerbil action figure? It would be the pinnacle of her collection! And really show the other kids.

Still, all this effort for one toy? When did kids ever have to go through that much effort? Your toys at Christmas and birthdays didn't require such hoops to jump through like:
14131.title: For Winners Only

choices: Try the fat girl with the big basket of fries.
Try the lardy boy eating ice cream.
No dice, Brit is going to have to enter herself in the contest.
141312.content:
Saturday at 2pm was going to be the big eating contest with the newest Gerbert toy as the grand prize. And as Brit had heard more and more details about the contest the further her heart sank into her stomach. Which was really counterintuitive.

She'd heard of such eating contests before. Ones where participants had to choke down hot dogs or work their way through messy blueberry pies. The contest at Gerbert's was going to make those pale in comparison. Unlike other kinds of eating contests, which was about how many of a food you could eat, on Saturday it was just going to be one item.

Kid vs the Galactic Pizza Pie.

The Galactic Pizza Pie was huge and that was not putting the term lightly. It may have well been a galaxy, Brit remembered one from her ninth birthday. It was so huge they needed a special oven to cook it. Normally the Galactic Pizza Pie was cut into squares, you could feed an entirely party of kids with it and there would still be leftovers! It had five toppings; pepperoni, sausage, green pepper, pineapple and extra cheese.

And they expected one kid to finish all of that!

[in all actuality, management probably expected no contestant to finish the whole thing, so it would come down to who ate the most rather than who finished first]

Brit's chances for claiming the toy prize may as well have been at the other end of the universe (filled with sauce and cheese). Three days was just to short a time to get ready for such a contest! Brit was a fit, clever and energetic enough kid, so had the contest been literally anything else she would have had a shot at winning. But an eating contest where the stakes were not steaks but the Galactic Pizza Pie? No one alive would be able to stomach that thing.

Moping over these prospects, Brit returned to the main dining room. She heard the fading of music as the curtain closed on a Cosmic Crew show. The devotee Brit was so dejected she wasn't upset to have missed it. Resting her backpack up on a seat Brit struggled with the unnatural thought that she may never have that Gerbert toy. Some other kid would win it, they'll never have this contest again and no other chance to get the greatest Gerbert action figure ever would ever come up!

Gross hyperbole, in actuality, although don't expect Brit to have such forward thinking while her dreams were being slowly crushed.

Brit certainly didn't feel happy as she looked around the dining room, where other kids were content to eat. And eat some of them did. Brit wasn't blind, it was her own concepts of image that kept her from eating everything she wanted, she could tell that a certain kind of kid was attracted to Gerbert's. Not the chubby ones, the fat ones. Kids that ate too much on their plate and asked for more, Even now there were a handful of fat children about, any of them could be future competitors.

It was then that an idea hit into Brit's head. Winning this contest meant knowing someone who had a decent shot at finishing off a Galactic Pizza Pie. If Brit could convince another kid to eat in her stead, where she got the prize while the kid did all the work, then the Gerbert toy would be as good as hers. Things would have to go just right. Brit scanned the crowd of customers intently. Time was a-wasting.
141312.title: There Wasn't A Rule Against It

choices: Skip ahead to the big day in question.
Brit talks some more with Greta to earn her trust.
Maybe they should practice, to see if Greta could handle a Galactic Pizza.
1413121.content:
It wasn't long before Brit saw a girl that matched her inner list of criteria. Sat in a booth across the way talking to an older person, probably a parent or older sibling, was a girl dressed entirely in orange. A light orange shirt and dark orange shorts that didn't entirely cover her belly. Brit could see that under the table a bit of the girl's skin was uncovered. Above the table the girl, with reddish orange hair that matched her color motif, had a mountain of fries in a big basket.

As Brit watched the redheaded girl did most of the fry munching, happily talking and giggling with the presumed family member. Brit felt herself teething her tongue in anticipation, waiting for her moment to catch the girl alone. Soon enough the older person headed to the bathroom, leaving the tubby redhead to eat her fries. Working up her courage, Brit walked over to the booth.

Getting closer to the redhead, Brit could see that she looked to be about the same age as her. There was a smattering of freckles across her chubby cheeks. The girl had a wrapper laid out before her where she mixed ketchup and mustard together into an orange sauce with her fries before eating another. From what Brit could tell the fry basket was another party sized portion, of which the girl looked to be eating with no issue.

If Brit ever hoped on winning the Gerbert toy, it rested on this girl.

"H-H-Hi," Brit asked awkwardly, catching the girl licking condiment off her lips. To Brit's delight the girl smiled and returned the greeting.

"Hello!" It was a very jovial tone of voice. Brit pretended that her backpack was too heavy.

"Mind if I sit here a moment?" she asked. Luckily the girl accepted. "My name is Brit Tanner."

"Brit," the girl repeated. "That's a nice name. My name is Greta Heinz."

Greta had an odd accent that Brit couldn't place. Once she was sitting she could note that Greta had more freckles than she had anticipated, along with bright green eyes. Greta twisted the wrapper around to offer the sauces. "Did you want some fries?"

"S-Sure," Brit said, taking a fry to dunk as she worked out a conversation in her head. Now that she was here she just needed to get Greta's interest without making her none the wiser. "I haven't seen you before. Do you like coming to Gerbert Gerbil's?"

"Oh yes!" Greta said enthusiastically. "Ever since we move my cousin takes me to Jer-bil's." Greta bounced a bit in her seat, having another handful of fries. Now that Brit thought about it, she hadn't seen this girl before but she had heard about some people recently moving to town, which must mean Greta's family.

This was perfect! It would mean Greta hadn't had any chance to have heard about Brit before, and she probably didn't know about the contest either! "I like coming to Gerbert's as well too!" Brit matched Greta's enthusiasm. "Are you doing anything this Saturday?"

"No," Greta asked, curious.

"Because they're having a special contest at two," said Brit, trying to downplay the particulars. "You have to try to eat this large pizza. There's this prize I want but I don't have the stomach for it. The only person who could win it would need to like to eat."

Brit had found herself a champion. During the explanation Greta had paused mid fry, ketchup mustard mix plopping back onto the wrapper as the chubby Greta sat there, a look of excitement spreading across her face. "I like to eat! Do you think many would be there, at contest? I don't know anybody around here."

That was the clincher. Brit could wrap this naive foreign accented Greta around her finger. "You know me now, don't forget. And if you win me first prize I'll be your best friend forever."

Greta smiled at that. "Sure, I was hoping to meet a new friend!"

That was step one of Brit's plan out of the way. Now there was just the event itself to prepare for. Brit made a show of needing to re-buckle her shoe so she could duck under the table for another look at Greta's belly. It was wide and plump, about an inch of stubborn skin refusing to stay clothed around the rim of her belly. Brit didn't know how much Greta had been eating but perhaps, on an empty stomach, she'd be a shoe-in to win that contest. And Brit would get the Gerbert toy.
1413121.title: Introducing Greta

choices: Courtney gets some food to eat.
A bashful Courtney tails after some other kids, watching them.
She finds something to distract her until it's time to go home.
142.content:
We will be home by eight.

Jin is unavailable to take you from school.

Hanna sends her love from Argentina.

Leftover mushu pork is in the fridge.

There is money under the spice rack.


Short, hastily scrawled notes dotted the inside of the Chiu household. Each of them meant for Courtney. A quiet girl that hid behind her glasses and bulky sweaters. Each note, of which there were varied others, indicating a life available to her family. A life away from her.

Courtney didn't know if she was a disappointment or undesired company from her family. They were always frequently busy and never around all that much. It made her reliable, self-dependant and able to keep house. And it made her very lonely.

Courtney mindlessly ate the two portions of mushu pork left. At age eleven she was a sizable girl, moon faced and rotund round the middle. Most of the time when she was left to her own devices she had nothing to do but eat. Her family, although absent, always made sure she was well fed.

Courtney's family had immigrated to this country before she was born. While they had gotten some roots into the community there weren't many of the neighbors they knew personally. Courtney hadn't really gotten the chance to meet any kids her own age. She was a studious although painfully shy girl. Left alone in a quiet house.

After dinner, her stomach still rumbled. She eyed the location of the spice rack with the promised money. Anticipating that she had the rest of the afternoon to herself, Courtney stood to retrieve the money and head to the one place that offered her some happiness.

Gerbert Gerbil & the Cosmic Crew.



It was always easy to see the restaurant from a ways off. The building was painted with planets, stars and spaceships, the sign outlined in neon. The inside was just as visually stimulating. Compared to the quiet life for Courtney at an empty house it was never quiet at Gerbert's. The bleeps and bloops of games from the arcade, the crash of balls from the playroom ball pit, a diminished chorus of happy birthday from some far off lucky kid. Bright, neon colors and cosmic patterns as the checkered tiles and wallpaper hinted at glow in the dark paint. The smells, it was mainly the smells that always drew in Courtney whenever she arrived at the restaurant. The food, food she knew well. An americana hodgepodge from iconic pizzas, milkshakes, burgers, fried foods, desserts.

There was a hint of a smile to Courtney's usually glum face. Gerbert's was always a more exciting place than her own life.
142.title: Misery's Company

choices: They're mean, teasing Courtney on the spot!
They're friendly, as they invite Courtney to join them.
They ignore Courtney for now, although they act very strangely.
1422.content:
While Courtney did love the food at Gerbert's, she was satisfied for the time being from the mushu pork she had eaten. Her main reason for coming here whenever her family left her alone was to see the other kids and families. She liked watching them although she was too scared to go up and talk to strangers.

Sometimes Courtney felt like she was part of a group of friends, watching them all crowd around an arcade game to beat the high score, or trade their tickets for prizes at the counter. She'd even watched what the kids a few tables away were eating and ordered it for herself, just to pretend that she was sharing a meal with them.

Although Courtney couldn't watch the other kids for too long without them noticing. The young asian girl had learned to curb her watching with taking interest in some other game when tailing other kids in the arcade. Once some boys had noticed her watching and talking loudly about her weight and glasses so much it embarrassed her.

Today Courtney saw a group of friends almost immediately. There were two boys and two girls, about her age, who looked to have just arrived at Gerbert's before she had, as they set their backpacks in a booth. They made a beeline to the arcade, Courtney shadowing them.

There was a black boy with short hair wearing a local softball jersey. He was arguing who amongst the Cosmic Crew was the better character, Gerbert Gerbil or Hippo Don, with a red haired boy with lots of freckles and green shorts. With them was a girl who looked an awful lot like the freckled boy, with her own red hair and freckles, a close sibling. And rounding out this quartet was a pale girl with brown hair. She was chunky, her purple dress was snug, although she was not close to Courtney's size.

The girls laughed at a joke Courtney couldn't hear. It must have been at the boys' expense, as they looked shocked and told the girls off by name.

Over the course of the next several minutes Courtney had gathered each of their names. The black boy was Marcus, the freckled boy was Sawyer and his sister was Sabrina. The remaining girl was named Nadine.

Even though the cluster of friends went from game cabinet to game cabinet, with Courtney watching them, it looked like they couldn't decide on what to do together. Sawyer wanted to do a physical game like basketball hoops or skeeball, while Marcus and Sabrina wanted the first play of contrasting video games. Nadine complained about getting something to eat, as she was hungry.

It was in the midst of their argument about what to do that the freckled twins, Sawyer and Sabrina, spotted Courtney looking at them. At their prompting Marcus and Nadine turned around as well before Courtney could look away. She froze up, caught staring with baited breath as the other kids regarded her existence.
1422.title: A Group of Friends

choices: Try some more games for more tickets.
Actually, a prize machine is more her speed.
Skeeball has worked up a bit of an appetite, time for food.
14222.content:
“Hey kid! You like skeeball?”

Courtney reflexively nodded, although more out of panic than anything.

“Cool,” Sawyer pumped his fist into the air. “Tie-breaker!”

“We don’t even know who she is,” his twin sister Sabrina said.

Nadine bounded up. “Hi! What’s your name?”

“C-Courtney,” Courtney mumbled just loud enough to hear.

“Courtney. Awesome,” Sawyer’s attention immediately turned in the direction of the skeeball games. “Then we’re decided on skeeball first. Hope you’ve got a good arm Courtney.”

There were many games in the arcade that Courtney had never played before. Skeeball was one of them. She stared dumbfounded at the line of ramps leading up to the targets.

“It’s easy,” Marcus said, although he sounded bored. “You want to roll the balls up to sink them into those holes. Those tubes in the back and center are worth the most points.”

Courtney nodded again, then realized she had to put money in the machine. However she only had the cash her family had left her.

“You need quarters for this,” Nadine chuckled. “Here, I already traded mine and I don’t feel like playing.”

Courtney traded one of her fives for a handful of quarters. She was the last one to activate her machine, as Sawyer, Sabrina and Marcus were already playing. She watched how they shot the balls down the ramp before she tried it herself.

She didn’t have the best hand-eye coordination so most of her balls ended up missing their targets, falling down into the bottom hole for 10 points each. Marcus and Sawyer were highly competitive, with Marcus coming out with the most tickets after a round of plays.

“No!” Sawyer whined. “I was going to beat you this time!”

“It’s all in the wrist,” Marcus said, although for him it was a hollow victory. “Can we play something else? I’m tired of skeeball all the time.”

Sabrina was counting up her tickets, having edged past her brother in score. “What does Courtney want to do?”

“W-Whatever you want to do.”

“Aren’t you going to take your tickets?”

“Oh,” Courtney knelt down, tearing off the meager string of five tickets from the machine.

“That’s barely enough for a pack of gum,” Nadine said. “You’ll need more tickets for a good prize. I like the machines that give you prizes right away.”

“But yeah, Courtney,” Sawyer spoke up, “sorry for putting you on the spot earlier. What do you really want to do?”
14222.title: Joining In

choices: Pink - Courtney wins.
Orange - Sabrina wins.
Purple - Nadine wins.
142222.content:
Courtney blinked a bit. Then, recalling Nadine’s sentiment about prizes that matched her own, she made a choice. If she wasn’t that good at games she wouldn’t have any tickets for the prize counter.

“There is the capsule machine over by the playroom entrance,” Courtney said.

There were signs of delight amongst everyone’s faces, which made Courtney feel like she was being included.

“Yeah,” Sawyer said, “that machine is cool!”

“And we’ve got enough people for a race,” Marcus said.

They walked over to the capsule machine. It was huge, taller than an adult, with a giant hopper of prize capsules at the top. Each plastic orb was a single color, opaque so you couldn’t tell what was inside until you opened it. The machine was in low light mode until it was activated. Inside the case were numerous twisting paths, chutes, funnels, lifts and jumps that dispensed the capsules out the little doors on the bottom of the machine.

Courtney stuck in some quarters and twisted the knob, dispensing a capsule from the hopper. It went into a clear funnel with two twisting arms that slid from the side, keeping the capsule popping up and down in the sealed funnel. Soon Sawyer, Sabrina, Marcus and Nadine had their quarters inserted as well, more capsules joining in the mixing funnel. Above the coin slot there was a set of flashing lights pointing to a button labeled RELEASE.

"I'll pick Green!" Sawyer said.

"Orange," Sabrina said.

Marcus took Blue and Nadine took Purple.

"Guess that leaves me with Pink," Courtney said. It wasn't her favorite color but it was all that was left. Sure, a single person could hit the RELEASE button right away if they just wanted one capsule but the real fun was filling up the mixing funnel. Upon release the scrambled capsules would have to roll through several routes in a race to see which got to the bottom first. Kids liked to pool their quarters and bet which color would get to the bottom first. The prizes were almost ancillary; small toys, keychains, sticker packs or tasty tasty treats.

Marcus hit the button. Whirring lights and a muted klaxon went off in the machine. The rotator retracted and the mixing funnel popped open. Each of their capsules dribbled down the splitter, some going along ramps and others in tubes. Blue bounced off a drum into a series of seesaw drops. The kids eyes darted back and forth, barely able to track their pick of color.

And then the first capsule fell into the exit chute, soon followed by three others and a straggler. Which one ended up in first?
142222.title: Prize Machine

choices: That night, at home, things get even stranger.
Courtney doesn't want the star. Trade it to someone else?
Leave it at Gerbert's, Courtney doesn't want to keep it.
1422221.content:
"Pink wins." Marcus retrieved the capsule, handing it over. "That was you, wasn't it Courtney?"

Courtney took her capsule, speechless. She rarely won at anything. More to the point, she never had the friends to play with up until now, that this group of friends invited her into their ranks. She stared at her capsule blankly, trying to comprehend this newfound joy.

"And as always Sawyer is dead last," Marcus handed off the green capsule.

"Shut up," Sawyer said, eagerly popping open his prize. Dead last had scored him a comet shaped bicycle reflector. Marcus got a rubber ball, Sabrina got a sticker pack and Nadine had already unwrapped the first of a handful of candies. "*munch* Aren't you going to open yours, Courtney?"

"Oh, right." Courtney was snapped out of her deep thoughts as the rest gathered up the spent capsule halves, returning them to a bin on the side of the machine that asked kids to recycle the capsules. With both hands Courtney squeezed the middle of the capsule until it popped open. A faint glow came from inside.

"What is that--?"

Sabrina was awed, as was everyone else. Courtney was just dumbstruck as she took out her prize with one hand. It was a large, sparkling yellow star with a blue comet tail, brightening and dimming in an odd rhythm. If felt like a hard foam or candy coated gel snack, having more heft that Courtney had ever thought.

"Can I see?" Sawyer snatched it out of her hand.

His twin sister shoved him. "Courtney won that!"

"I know, I just want to see it." He opened his hand. The star laid there but it was dull. "Huh, why isn't it glowing?"

"Let me see," Marcus scrutinized it closely yet nothing changed. "Maybe the battery went out?"

After everyone had a turn looking at the star it returned to Courtney. The moment it entered her hand a faint glow emerged from the star again.

"That is freaky," Marcus said.

Courtney wasn't sure what to say. Having the star pulsating with light would get tiresome so she shut it back up in the prize capsule.

"Why does it only glow when Courtney holds it?" Sawyer asked.

Courtney couldn't think of an answer. As much as she had always wanted some attention from kids she could call friends she was getting uncomfortable being the center of attention. After she had stored the star away the conversation soon turned to other topics as the group debated on what to do next. Withdrawing herself from the discussion, Courtney cracked open the prize capsule just a peek.

The star was still glowing.

She wasn't paying attention to what her new friends were saying anymore. There was something strange about this star, something weird Courtney couldn't place, leaving an unfathomable hollow feeling in the pit of her stomach.
1422221.title: The Star

choices: Follow Freddy as he finds himself in the one place he hates the most.
Follow Chuck as he plans new ways to scare his brother with his friends.
Follow Freddy and Chuck together. What new fright is in store?
143.content:
For Freddy, the last five nights had been intense.

Not that he could tell his family. The other kids wouldn't believe him either. It was just too unbelievable of a story, a hamster from outer space terrorizing you every night.

Yet terrorize him it did.

Freddy Fairbank was a small, wimpy looking lad no greater than 8 years old. His dark eyes showed a lack of sleep, his hair was combed back neatly saved for one curl in the front. In his grey and black striped pajamas he had a hint of a drooping potbelly. Gotten from the cookies and other snacks he would squirrel away to his room. He needed something to keep his strength up during the nights when the terror from Gerbert Gerbil & the Cosmic Crew came to scare him.

Freddy wasn't like other kids his age. To anyone else, it would have been awesome living just down the block from the space themed family restaurant. Not for Freddy. He hated Gerbert's. He had always been scared of the place, even his first memory at the location was unnerving.

"It'll be okay, Moolia." Freddy hugged the cow plushie closer to himself for comfort. The only thing Freddy liked about Gerbert's was his toys, although those toys were a scant few. The tri-colored spotted cow was the only survivor.

Gripping his flashlight, Freddy passed the beam over each entry point to his room. His was at the end of the hall and there was a door to either side of the room leading to different halves of the house. Just when he thought is was quiet again the chiming of the clock in the hall startled him. Three chimes. Three am. Yet there was another sound behind the chimes. Thumping. Something was coming this way.

Every nerve wanted to keep Freddy bound at his bed. Yet he got up, stepped lightly towards one door. For a tense moment he strained to hear what was beyond the door. Ultimately he risked it and cast out his flashlight down the hall. Nothing. Just the pictures on the wall, the grandfather clock and closed doors. It was quiet. Too quiet.

That's when Freddy heard the monster creeping up behind him.

Freddy turned to late to dodge the claw that grabbed him by the shoulder. There was a horrid fuzzy face with its mouth open, long teeth ready to gnaw off his nose. Its fur was mangy and its eyes covered by white film. A broken astronaut's helmet framed the monster's face.

Freddy screamed and screamed. His legs gave out from under him as he passed out, unconscious.



The next morning Freddy awoke on the floor, cold, his stomach in knots with a sour sick feeling. His neck ached from the poor position he had slept in after collapsing. Panic raced through his mind as he remembered the fright of the monster that followed him home from Gerbert's. The feeble light of day was enough to cast the fears to the side for now. His tummy rumbled, his teeth felt like moss was growing on them. To replenish his nerves he ate one of the snack cakes from his stash, then fastidiously hid away the rest of the snacks and empty wrapper.

Freddy hoped for a good morning. He crossed to his closet, opening the doors to get dressed for school.

The monster astronaut hamster burst out of his closet!

Freddy had spent all of his screams last night. He crumpled into the fetal position, holding his legs against his pooching belly as he cried into the carpet. He hoped the monster wouldn't hurt him.

Then Freddy heard the laughter. Familiar laughter.

"Ha ha hah, you're such a crybaby Freddy." The little boy looked up at his tormentor. He recognized the voice, the build, the true face behind the horrid mask once it was removed.

"Chuck!" Freddy cried.

"You peed your pants again, crybaby?" His brother Chuck Fairbank, older by a few years, stooped to check. Chuck was a beefy kid and the effort of scaring Freddy had worked up a bit of a sweat. Freddy recalled the embarrassing memory from the second night of this terror. His first attempt at staying awake was to drink a lot of soda. That proved to be a terrible idea, as the moment Freddy had been scared he lost control of his bladder, wetting the bed.

"Chuck. Freddy. Breakfast time."

"Not a word about this, right crybaby?" Chuck prodded his prone brother with a foot. Then he hurried off to breakfast. Freddy stayed in his room, trying to dry his tears until he was called for breakfast the second time. His mean bully of a brother had Freddy plenty scared. He couldn't say a word about being frightened, of the revelation that Chuck had been the one scaring him in a Hamster Louie mask for the past five nights. Freddy could only sit there at breakfast chewing on his food, trying to find some comfort, eating his fair share of toaster waffles close to the number that Chuck scarfed down.
143.title: Crybaby Freddy

choices: Some kids from school try to cheer up Freddy, although they end up teasing him.
At least he can order whatever he wants to eat thanks to dad's position.
Freddy comes across a new fright when he really wished he hadn't.
1431.content:
For Freddy the nightmare didn't end.

Sure, school was a brief relief. But Freddy always knew that the after school timeframe was inevitable. And day after day, Freddy found himself at Gerbert Gerbil's.

He couldn't help it. Freddy wished he could just go straight home after school but there wouldn't be anybody at home. He wasn't allowed to stay home by himself. Since the bus dropped them off up the street, opposite from their house on the other side of Gerbert's, the family restaurant and arcade became the mandatory after school waiting spot. Waiting for his dad to get off of work. He had an important position in the company and had to work their for long hours. Sometimes Freddy had to wait at Gerbert's for an hour, sometimes longer. Worse of all, his dad didn't understand that Freddy was scared of the place. It was too noisy and unnerving for Freddy to attempt any homework. Often he would be sitting off by himself in abject terror, a low building tension as he saw employees and the mascots roam the establishment.

Suffice to say Freddy never really had fun at Gerbert's. Today was a day like any other. Freddy rebuckled his shorts after leaving the restroom. He hoped Chuck wasn't out there somewhere in the restaurant waiting to pounce on him again. His brother took evil delight from seeing how uncomfortable Gerbert's made Freddy.

For such a glum little boy there were few constructive outlets.
1431.title: The Place Of Nightmares

choices: Eh, they'll think of something. Chuck and the gang go find something else to do.
The gang finds a different kid at Gerbert's to terrorize.
Freddy is soon lured into a horrid prank set up by the four of them.
1432.content:
"And then he's just curled up in ball on the floor, crying his eyes out!"

That earned fresh laughter from Chuck's friends as they sat in a booth at Gerbert Gerbil's, each with a giant malt and a mountain of onion rings between them.

Chuck noisily punctuated the tale from this morning by munching on an onion ring. He wiped the grease on his grey shirt. His hair was short, a buzz cut, an he had something of a hoggish demeanor. The weather was getting warm so he had opted for sandals.

"Man your brother is crybaby," said Diego Murrieta, grabbing another fistful of onion rings. Diego often wore red, rolling his r's due to his Spanish accented English. He looked the toughest out of the gang of friends, having a buff set of muscles not commonly seen on the prepubescent. "What's so scary about Gerbert's? It's just the dorky animals in outer space, there's nothing scary about that."

"There's plenty to be scared of," said Willy McCulley, his hair matching the hint of red on his cheeks. "When you're a snot nosed baby that looks like a shrimp next to one of the robots. First time my cousin came here she yelled her head off. Had to put a sock in her mouth to get her to shut up." Willy pulled at his green shirt. "Otherwise, Gerbert's is kinda lame. I don't see why we keep coming here."

"Bide your tongue!" said Toby Garcia, his face crestfallen to the point it looked like he had jowls. "Gerbert's is the place to hang. The onion rings are great, the malts are great, the pizza's great, the--"

"Something besides the whole menu you keep stuffing your gullet with!" Willy spat back. Although to be fair, Willy wasn't a skinny kid either. Yet out of all of the upsized troublemakers Toby was the tubbiest. The blue shirt covering his stomach almost pressed into the table.

"Yeah, shut up Willy the food's great," Chuck said. Although not as big as Toby he was plenty big. And although he wasn't as nasty as Willy or as strong as Diego, he has all of their best (or worst) attributes rolled into one package. From his personality alone Chuck was the de facto leader of the little gang of bullies.

"Besides, yeah, Gerbert is dumb but Hippo Don is hilarious. Although nothing beats Hamster Louie."

"Hamster Louie isn't even a real character," Diego challenged.

"Is too!" Chuck retorted, chucking the remains of an onion ring at Diego. "They just don't advertise him, see, but he's strung up in the back room. Made him the perfect character to scare Freddy with." Chuck wiped the grease off his chin thoughtfully. "Although I need to find a new way to scare his pants off. Something that makes him cry even harder."

That got the gang of bullies to thinking. Well, three of them at any rate as Toby just kept helping himself to onion rings.
1432.title: Chuck And The Gang

Skateboarding injury (broken ribs)
144.content:
"Marcus! Tobias! Wait just a minute!"

In typical fashion for Zuri's younger brothers, the moment they stepped into Gerbert Gerbil's they were off like bottle rockets. Normally Zuri could keep up with them but not today. It was the first chance she'd managed to convince her folks to let her go to Gerbert's.

Zuri had a mop of curly hair and a purple jacket over her t-shirt. She was the oldest of her siblings that still liked going to Gerbert Gerbil's, which left her in charge over Marcus and Tobias. And she was a very energetic girl so normally this was no problem.

"Oof! Huff..."

Well, up until Zuri had gotten herself hurt in her favorite pastime. She didn't want the injury to stop her from having fun at Gerbert's, having finally recovered enough to be out and about. Yet getting here had shown her energy was tapped. Moving too fast made it hurt all the more.

"When I get my hands on them," Zuri winced. She still had to keep up her show of force to boss her little brothers whenever they got out of line. However, the extent of her injury was going to make that a problem.

What is ailing Zuri Matthews?"
